There is a desk in the warehouse; it is usually kept locked; I have the key.
Do you sit there to receive parcels, or when parcels are brought there, do you take them in, and lock them up? - I do.
Do you usually keep the desk locked? - Always.

Did you mark any money on leaving that desk? - Yes, thirty-seven guineas, and twenty shillings in silver, and four half crowns; all these I marked some days before, about four days, except seven guineas, seven guineas I marked over night; I had thirty guineas marked four or five days.
How much money had you in that desk marked? - That I cannot tell; I kept the unmarked in a purse by itself, and the marked in a leather purse, and the silver in a wooden dish.

I suppose the occasion of your marking the money was, that you had lost money, and wanted to detect the thieves? - On the 16th of September, between eight and nine, I was sitting on the steps, and the prisoner brought an old lanthorn, which his master bid him put into the warehouse; I gave the prisoner the large key to open the door; there is a key to the desk, another to the door.

What did you do with the key of the desk? - I had it in my pocket; he stopped about twenty minutes in the warehouse; and few a minutes after his taylor came down the street, and they went down to drink a glass, I sent for the key to go to wash myself; I took the large key from him, I immediately opened the desk and I saw the leather purse which had the thirty-seven guineas was reversed, turned upside down, after that I took and counted them, and there was only thirty-six, I told the silver, and I missed one of the half crowns; I locked the desk and went to my master, and told him; my master told me to go into the warehouse; and he came in and called up the prisoner and accused him; the prisoner said he never robbed him of a farthing; I told him he had taken a guinea and half-a-crown, and some halfpence that morning; my master desired him to take the money out of his pocket; accordingly my master found the guinea and half-a-crown upon him, knowing it to be mine, as he knew my mark.
Did you see the guinea and the half-crown that he produced out of his pocket? - Yes, the constable has it, it had my mark; I am sure it was in the desk when the young man went into the warehouse.
Are you sure you had not paid away any of this marked money? - No, I kept it; it was not circulating money, I kept it on purpose to catch the prisoner.
How could your desk be got open? - I suppose by the virtue of a false key.
Was that key searched for? - No.
Jury. Did you pay that money to nobody? - No, I never passed it.
What is the mark? - There is a horse upon the guinea, and I cut his leg with a dash; and on the half crown, opposite the king on the near side there is a dash.
(Shewn to the Jury.)
Mr. Garrow. You told my Lord, I think, that thirty-seven guineas had been marked for four days? - Yes.
Was the same mark on all the guineas? - All the same mark.
You could not tell one from the other? - No.
How long is it since you began marking guineas? - When I had about seven or eight; I kept adding to the heap, but never took any from it.

Do you mean to swear now, that in no one instance any one of these guineas was taken out and got into circulation; could it not happen by accident or any other way? - I never meant to take any out, it was a thing impossible, for nobody had a key to this desk but myself.
Was not this young man searched directly, to see if he had a key? - No, he was not.
Have you lost any of your marked guineas before? - Yes, several times.
How many had you got before you missed any? - I cannot say, then I kept putting more, every five or six days there was a guinea taken.
Somebody, however, at different times took out a marked one? - Yes, he had.
Had you lost any of your silver? - No; I used three different marks, these thirty-seven were marked alike.
What was the mark on the half-crown? - A dash on the tail side.

WILLIAM BISHOP
sworn.
Are you this young man's master? - Yes.

Do you remember Mr. Thompson's evidence, and what be supposed had been done by this young man? - Perfectly well; Mr. Thompson called me up in the Coach-office, on the 16th of September, and told me that the prisoner had been taking money out of the desk; he ordered me to call him into the office; I called him up, and Mr. Thompson told him to take what money he had out of his pocket; and he laid down the money he had, which was part of it mine, and among that money was a guinea and half-a-crown, which he said belonged to Wadsworth our book-keeper; Wadsworth claimed it, and said it was his, and came out of the desk; the lock was not broke as I observed; he was not searched for a false key; his general character was a good one.
Mr. Garrow. Did not the prisoner desire to be searched? - I believe he said, you may search me if you will.
Prisoner. I am innocent; I said gentlemen search me; I leave the rest to my counsel; I am in the warehouse sometimes two or three hours.
Mr. Bishop. I gave him the lanthorn into the gateway, and I told him to go into the office and clean it; that accounts for some part of the time.
The prisoner called eleven witnesses who all gave him a very good character.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the London Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

859.
JOHN BECKETT
,
THOMAS SIMS
, and
HENRY NELSON
, were indicted for that
they, on the 16th day of October , two hundred and fifteen pounds weight of lead, value 30 s. belonging to
John Stephens
, and affixed to a certain building of his, feloniously did rip, cut, and carry away .

It appearing since the bill was found, that Mr. Stephens has no interest in the premises, the prisoners were ALL
ACQUITTED .

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

860.
JOHN SAVAGE
,
GEORGE DOBSON
, and
THOMAS OAKES
, were indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 18th day of September , one cotton gown, value 10 s. and one linen petticoat, value 4 s. the property of
Windham Madan
, one other cotton gown, value 10 s. one cotton petticoat, value 4 s. the property of
Elizabeth Bingham
, spinster .
The prosecutors and witnesses not appearing, the prisoners were ALL ACQUITTED .
Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

861.
JOSEPH PERRY
was indicted, for
feloniously stealing, on the 5th day of September , one steel watch-chain, value 6 d. a seal, value 6 d. a silver penny, and a piece of foreign coin, value an halfpenny , the property of
Joseph Blake
.

JOSEPH BLAKE
sworn.

I lost the things mentioned in the indictment the second day of Bartholomew-fair
, pretty near seven, it was light at the time, but little light; the prisoner came alongside of me, and he snatched my chain; he had been along-side of me three or four minutes.

Did your chain break? - Yes, and there was two pieces fixed to it, there was a yellow seal; I had it about a week, there was a piece of silver coin, and a piece of foreign coin, plated with silver, fixed to the chain; I saw my property stealing from this hole in my breeches, and I struck him with this very same hand, the right hand; says I, you want to rob me of my watch, and you have got my chain; who me! says he, and he dropped it directly; I saw the chain fall out of his own hand; I picked it up myself, the constable has had the care of it ever since; then he began to beat me, and cut my eye and face; I hallooed out constable; a man came the next day to me that pretended to be a constable; he called me out; says he, Mr. Blake I want to speak to you.
Prisoner. Did not we fight in the fair? - I was not fighting, I was defending myself.
Prisoner. Did not you say to me, you G - d d - d b - r, if it had not been for my pocket you would have taken my watch? - No.

MARY BLAKE
sworn.

I am the wife of
Joseph Blake
; I was at Bartholomew-fair the second day of the fair, and as we were coming through the fair, we were surrounded by a very great mob, and my husband was crying out how he had lost his watch; I had hold of his jacket for fear of losing him; I saw him strike the prisoner, I am sure it was him, I saw him by the side of my husband before; my husband's hat flew off in the fight, and I went to save it; I did not see the prisoner do any thing to my husband; while I was stooping down somebody

snatched at my cloak; then I did not see my husband again till I saw his nose bleeding and a black eye; then the constable took the prisoner away; I believe his name is Tillcock, and Dunchin wanted to make it up, and give my husband three or four shillings; my husband said he had lost his watch; after I saw his watch on the tap-room table facing Wood-street Compter; the officer asked him if he had lost any thing, and he said then, he only lost his chain, and he gave the officer his watch-chain from his waistcoat pocket; it had a brass chain and two pieces of coin.
Prisoner. The first time she came she said she knew nothing of the business? - I gave the same account I do now; I did not say that I knew nothing of it.

WILLIAM DINCHIN
sworn.

I was bred to the sea; I get my bread by rigging; I was with the prosecutor and his wife; at this time it was between six and seven; I cannot recollect what day of the week or fair; I was behind Blake with his wife, I saw Blake striking at a man, I had not seen the man near him before, and there were a parcel of people together, and they got a fighting; I could not get to the man, and I looked for the woman, and the constables had got the prisoner; and I saw Blake's face cut; Blake said in the fair the prisoner wanted his watch; I saw no more of it till we came to the public house, and Blake took out his chain, and said see how it is broke; and the constable Tillcock asked him for it, and he gave it to him.
(Describes it.)
Court to Mrs. Blake. What did your husband say? - He said the man wanted to rob him of his watch.

RICHARD TILCOCK
sworn.

I am a constable; as we were coming down Bartholomew-fair there were a number of people together, and a person called out, constable, I have lost my watch; I saw the prosecutor's face all bloody; he said the man is there, and pointed to the prisoner; the prisoner had his coat off, my partner, Sargeson, he took hold of him and delivered him to me; I searched him, I found nothing upon him; he gave charge of him, for that he had lost his watch.

Are you sure of that? - Yes; this charge was first given in Smithfield, and afterwards when he came to the Compter; I asked him for his address, and he gave it in Nightingale-lane; then he pulled out the chain, and said the prisoner forced the chain from his watch; he did not say then that he had taken his watch; I think he was sober, but being an Italian I could hardly understand him; but I am sure he said in the fair that he had lost his watch: I have had the chain ever since (Deposed to) I swear to the chain and the pieces of coin; I have kept the watch also.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

This Blake was going on in Bartholomew-fair; I was before him and he knocked me down, and said I took this watch; I got up and asked him what that was for; he said I had got his watch, then we fought two or three rounds, I hit him on the nose and gave him a black eye, I suppose that exasperated him, and he run into the Crown, and called for two constables; they came and took hold of me; nothing was said about the chain; he had the chain and his watch then; then he laid hold of his chain, and said, you God d - d b - r, if it was not for this hole I should have lost my watch; then we came to Wood-street Compter, I thought it was for striking him; I knew nothing of this till next morning; then when we went before the Alderman he had his chain in his hand, and said I broke it off; if you will hear this witness.

WILLIAM SARGESON
sworn.
I am a chandler; I live in Grub-street; I am a housekeeper.

Are you a constable? - Not this year; I have been several years running; I was employed by the Marshal, along with Mr. Tillcock in Bartholomew fair; there were a number of constables employed at that time.

Prisoner. Did not you see the chain hanging to the man's breeches after this affair that he charged me with; when the cry was, constables, I have lost my watch? - I and Tillcock made our way into the crowd; I was the first of the two; I laid hold of the prisoner; Tillcock was at the same time as close as he could be; I gave him into Tillcock's hands; Tillcock gave him leave to put on his coat; I was keeping off the mob as much as I could; the prosecutor was close to my elbow; before we got to the end of Duck-lane, Tillcock was before the prisoner; Mr. Blake was along with me; he laid hold of his watch chain; I was about three steps behind, with the prosecutor close by my elbow; Mr. Blake swore a great oath, with a bloody b-g-r that if it had not been for a round turn in his breeches, he would have had his watch; then he pulled at the chain, and pulled up the chain; I did not see the watch, but I saw the chain; I replied, put your chain in, or otherwise you will be done of it yet; this was after I let the prisoner put on his coat; I swear his chain appeared fast, the same as mine is now; and I said, put your chain in, or else you will be done of it; the crowd was so, I could hardly keep them off of Tillcock and the prisoner; he pulled so hard at it with a terrible oath that he drew up his breeches waistband.
What was the oath he made use of? - The latter part of the oath was bloody b - g - r.
What did he say when he made use of that oath? - That he had done him of his watch if it had not been for that round turn.
What? - That he would have got his watch, had it not been for that round turn.

Just now you said something else, and I want you to repeat it? - I cannot recollect the other part; he said, he had done him of his watch, if it had not been for that round turn; we went on to the compter; when we got to the public house to take his address; he then produced the chain loose.
Where did he produce it from? - I cannot tell.
Will you swear that he did not produce it from his waistcoat pocket? - Was I to swear so, I should swear more than I know; I do not know from what pocket he produced it; he did produce it.

Who was it that advised Mr. Blake to make it up with the prisoner? - As we came along Love-lane, the prisoner called me first, and desired I would speak to the prosecutor that he would make him satisfaction for striking of him; I believe Tillcock heard the words; I could not tell who had been the first aggressor, not then; upon which I told Blake, that the prisoner was willing to make him satisfaction for striking of him.
Did Tillcock hear that? - I do not know; Blake was five or six steps forward all the way; I spoke to Blake; he refused it; and I told the prisoner he would have nothing to do with it.
How happened that you was not constable this year? - I do not know; I have been a substitute several years.
Was you ever turned out of office? - No, my Lord.
Never? - No.
When you was at the Compter the charge was made? - Yes.

Now on hearing this gross and abominable charge made of stealing this chain; when you saw it found in the man's breeches before; what did you say to Mr. Blake on that occasion? - I did not say any thing to Mr. Blake then; it did not strike my mind at that time; I mentioned it the next morning to the Magistrate.
Why did not you tell Mr. Blake,

"you must be a very bad man; it is but a very few minutes ago that you shewed me this chain whole; you must have broke it from your fob?" - My Lord, the truth is, it did not strike my mind till the next morning; I had quite forgot what passed in the street at that moment; the next morning I told the Magistrate of the proceeding.
Who subpoened you here? - The prisoner.
Did you come by a subpoena, or without one? - By a subpoena.
Have you got that subpoena? - I believe I have.
(Produces it.)
When did you receive this subpoena? - On Thursday afternoon, I think it was.
The prisoner was in the room when this charge was made against him? - He was put into the compter before the chain was produced.
You did not go to the Magistrate that night? - No, not before the next day.
What did the prisoner say to the charge? - The prisoner denied it; and I acquainted the Magistrate what I have acquainted your Lordship.

What did Blake say to that? - Blake gave me ill language, but it was immaterial; the Magistrate thought I had been fee'd by the prisoner; Blake persisted in the charge, and first of all he said, that he took it out of the prisoner's hand; then he varied from it, and said, that the prisoner threw it down, and he picked it up, and first he sung out that he had lost his watch.
How came you to say that the prosecutor gave the same account that he has given in Court? - I was there when he was examined.
How do you know what account he has given now? - I hear that he gives account that he took it up.
From whence have you heard that? - That might not be the identical word.
How do you know what he said in this Court, have you received any message out of this Court from the prisoner here? - No, upon my oath.
Nor had any intelligence from him? - No farther than the subpoena.

Have not you been in Court during the whole time the prosecutor was examined? - Yes, my Lord, I was; I did not hear the witnesses for the prisoner ordered out; I heard the witnesses for the prosecutor ordered out; or else it would have been the same to me; I came here with no tale; I never saw the man before nor had any conversation with him; Tillcock and the prisoner were before, and Blake and me were behind some steps.

How did the prisoner get at you to subpoena you? - He was examined three times at Guildhall before he was committed, and there he got my name; I met his wife one day promiscuously in St. Giles's; I knew nothing of the man; I met her once since that again.
How came you to know it was his wife? - They said so when he was examined; she attended the examination every day; but Tillcock can tell as well as me.
What sort of a woman was she? - A young woman, appearing about two or three and twenty.
Did you give the man's wife or him your direction? - Why I do not know whether I did mention it at the Castle.
It is impossible you can have forgot? - I believe I did at the Castle, before Tillcock and the prosecutor.
Did you give that direction in writing? I believe he wrote it in writing.
Did you give it in writing? - I really cannot say who wrote it; going up Guildhall yard, Blake's wife says to him, never mind, swear that you took it out of his hand.
Was you employed this fair time by the Marshal? - Yes.
Which of the Marshals? - Mr. Miller.
Did he pay you for your attendance? - Yes; he gave us an order for the money.
Court to Prosecutor. Did you ever say at any time that you took the chain out of the prisoner's hand? - It is false, every thing; because I never spoke to him.
Did you say that before the Magistrate? - I do not recollect that I did; I told the Magistrate that I saw the chain in his hand and he dropped it directly.
Did you ever say that you took it out of the prisoner's hand? - I picked it up directly.
Court. Let Mrs. Blake go out of Court.

Now in Guildhall yard, when you came away, did your wife say to you, never mind, swear that you took it out of his hand? - No, she said no such thing to me; why should I swear any thing that is not true.
Did your wife ever tell you to swear that? - No, she never told me nothing.
Was not it the last winess that desired you to make it up? - Yes.
When he wanted to make it up, what did he say? - He spoke to my other witness Dunchin twice; a man came to me twice from Sargesson; Sargesson never spoke to me; it was Dunchin that came to me.

Do you recollect coming home whether you put your hand into your pocket or into your fob? - I took out my chain and shewed it to
William Dunchin
, and put it directly into my green-shag waistcoat pocket; that was in the fair.

When you came in the house you shewed the chain to Tillcock, did you, when you was walking home, put your hand to your fob and say any thing to him? - I never spoke to him all the way home; the constable offered me two guineas the next day to make it up; says he, come here, I want to speak to you; says he, you are French, I know that very well, says he, you do not know the law of England; yes, says I; says he, he will be tried at the Old Bailey, and the costs to you will be sixty pounds; my wife was in the public house, at the sign of the Castle; he called me out to him; I wn out to him twenty yards.
Court. Call in Mrs. Blake
Did you go with Mr. Blake backwards and forwards to the Magistrate? - Yes, Sir, every day.
How do you and your husband get your living in Nightingale-lane? - Only by his going to sea.

Did you tell your husband any time, never mind, swear that he had the chain in his hand? - No; I always was quite against it; I wished to have no trouble with it; I am very sure I never told him, never mind it, swear that he had the chain in his hand; I could take my affidavy I never said such a word as that.
Court. Let Mr. and Mrs. Blake come forward, and let Sargesson stand up together.

Now Sargesson, Mr. and Mrs. Blake, on the solemn oath they have taken, have both positively sworn that what you have said is false; Mr. and Mrs. Blake swear positively, that there was no such word said, as never mind it, swear that he had the chain in his hand; now I ask you, upon your oath, whether you will still persist in what you have said? - Yes, I will, point blank, swear that she said to him in Guildhall-yard, going up on his shoulder, never mind, swear that you took the chain out of his hand.

Court to Mrs. Blake. When did you see Sargesson first, did you see him in your way home talking with your husband? - No, Sir, Sargesson came with us to the public house from the fair; he was first with my husband, then with the prisoner.

Did you hear any conversation between the fair and the public house, between Sargesson and your husband? - No farther than he wanted to persuade my husband to make it up; he said you had better take four or five shillings, and make it up, than let it go any farther; it will only cost you a deal of trouble.
To make what up? - I did not hear him say what.

Did you hear him say the b - g - r wanted totake away my watch? - No, Sir, I did not hear him say so, because he very seldom makes ude of that word; he might say it, but I did not hear him; we went to the public house in Guildhall-yard every day.
Do you remember Sargesson's beckoning your husband out for any thing? - Yes, Sir, I was sitting by at the same time.
How long was your husband out? - About a quarter of an hour.
You did not follow him to know what Sargesson said to him? - No, Sir, I did not; I asked him several times, but he did not tell me.

Court to Dunchin. Do you know whether you saw the watch and the chain separate in Smithfield or any time before he got to the compter? - Yes, Sir, as they were going through the fair, after the prisoner was in custody, the prosecutor took the chain in his hand, and put it into his waistcoat pocket; at the pu blic house he took out the chain of his watch out of his waistcoat pocket, and gave it to the constable; I saw him, as he was going along the fair, put it in his waistcoat pocket; I came with them to the public house; he had no conversation with Sargesson; he was going on in a passion, with his face bloody; and Sargesson came to me twice, to endeavour to make it up with the prosecutor, for it would only cost trouble, and I went to him the first time, says I, you have got your watch and your chain, what signifies; he said, he would have satisfaction.
Was there any conversation between the last witness, Sargesson, as he was walking through the fair to the public house and the prosecutor? - I did not take notice of any.

Did he say any thing to you about making up the blows or any thing of the kind? - No, he did not say any thing of the kind; Sargesson came to me another time, then he asked me to advise the man to make it up; he did not say a word that I know about blows or any thing, only to make it up, that it might not go any farther.
Did Sargesson say any thing at the public house that you recollect? - No, Sir.
He did not tell the prosecutor, why you are a bad man, you broke it yourself, or any thing of that kind? - No, Sir.

Did the prosecutor, at the public house, charge the prisoner with having taken his chain? - He did, and Sargesson said nothing to it; I was at the Castle the last day; but I cannot recollect whether the prosecutor was called out by any body or not.
Prosecutor. I came home the 21st of August; I bought the watch chain and key since I came home, because the watch I had when I was in the kingdom before; then I took it out of the kingdom.
GUILTY .
Transported for seven years .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

862.
JOHN GOSS
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 15th of September , one muslin handkerchief, value 10 d. the property of
James Langdale
.

JAMES LANGDALE
sworn.

I live on Ludgate-hill; on Friday the 15th of September, about eight in the evening, I was going up Holborn
, near Staples Inn; I cried stop thief, having missed my handkerchief; it was an English muslin handkerchief; I missed it in a moment; I saw it in his hand.
- ARCHIBALD sworn.

My Lord, I was coming down Holborn, about eight o'clock; I was about two yards off the pavement; I saw Mr. Langdale, and I saw the prisoner put his hand in Mr. Langdale's pocket, and pull out the handkerchief; I immediately seized the prisoner by the hand in which he had the handkerchief; I seized him with some violence, and we both came to the ground together, but I never let go the handkerchief; I called the prosecutor, and he claimed the handkerchief.
Jury. Did you see him pick the pocket? - I did.

JOHN JULIAN
sworn.
I rent part of a house in Houghton-street, Clare-market; I am a carpenter.
What is the prisoner? - He is a carpenter ; I have known him three years; he works with his father; he worked along side me three quarters of a year; he always bore a good character.

William Goss
. I am his father.
Court. I cannot ask you any questions.
GUILTY .
Publickly Whipped .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

863.
JAMES BUSKIN
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 9th day of October last, one silk and cotton handkerchief, value 1 s. the property of
James Moore
.

JAMES MOORE
sworn.

I live in Houghland-street, Tottenham-court-road; I lost a Barcelona handkerchief, on Monday, the 9th day of this month, between three and four o'clock, going up Holborn
, on the left side, near the church, I thought I felt some body at my pocket; I found nothing missing; I was not sure I had lost any thing; I buttoned up my pocket to prevent his taking it; I observed the prisoner following, but I am not sure it is the prisoner, I believe it is; I had not gone far, when I heard the cry of stop thief; and Scott held up the handkerchief, and told me my pocket was picked; it was a handkerchief of my wife's, and the only one I had of the kind; I believe it to be mine; I found I had lost one; I had the handkerchief about a week; I will not swear I had it that morning; I went into a stationer's shop, and gave my name.

ALEXANDER SCOTT
sworn.

I am engine keeper of St. Andrew's, Holborn; at half past two, on Monday, the 9th, I saw the prisoner with his right-hand, take the handkerchief out of Mr. Moore's pocket; I am sure of the prisoner; I saw him throw the handkerchief away.

JAMES SCOTT
sworn.
I was walking with my brother, and saw the prisoner pick Mr. Moore's pocket; I took him into custody; the last witness had the handkerchief.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

I was going up Holborn, and two more young fellows just behind me, and immediately that gentleman halloo'd out, that man has picked the man's pocket; and he crossed the way immediately, and laid hold of me; says I, what do you want with me; says he, you have picked the gentleman's pocket; he picked up the handkerchief off the ground; and he said I threw it into the apple-basket, or apple-stall that was there.
GUILTY .
Transported for seven years .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

864.
MATTHEW HUNT
was indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
John Parsons
, about the hour of seven in the night, on the 28th day of September last, and burglariously stealing therein a man's hat, value 6 s. a pair of breechees, value 1 s. a coat, value 20 s. a waistcoat, value 2 s. five pair of hose, value 8 s. two handkerchiefs, value 2 s. a pocket-book, value 3 d. the property of
Richard Akam
, in his dwelling house .

RICHARD AKAM
sworn.

I belong to Mr.
John Parsons
, at the Bull, on Holborn-hill
; I am ostler ; my lodging-room is joining the warehouse in the yard; my door was broke open, on the 28th day of September, about seven in the evening; I saw the wainscoting broke through the lost; and my chest was broke open; the things I lost are here; I have seen the prisoner before.

JANE SCANDERFIELD
sworn.

I saw
Robert Hunt
in the yard, about eight o'clock in the evening; and he came out with a bundle under his arm, with two hats on his head; I sit at the door with oysters; he went down Holborn-hill; I do not know what he had; I mistrusted he had something that did nor belong to him.

RICHARD YOUNGER
sworn.

Upon the information of the last witness, I went in pursuit after him, and found him at the Fleet-market, with the bundle under his arm, and two hats on his head; he made several plunges to get from me, but I told him it was of no use; I took him back to the Bull Inn; and the prosecutor swore to the hat.
(The constable produced the things, which were deposed to by the prosecutor.)
GUILTY Of stealing, but not of breaking and entering the dwelling house .
Transported for seven years .

865.
DAVID STEWART
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 1st day of June , one cotton gown, value 10 s. three yards of linen, value 4 s. one handkerchief, value 4 s. the property of
Ann Lawrence
.

ANN LAWRENCE
sworn.
I am in service; I live now with Mr. Green; I have lived with him ten weeks, but I am going to leave him.

Did you live with him as a servant ? - Yes; I took a hackney coach sometime back, but it is a long while ago; I cannot recollect how long, it is two sessions ago; the coachman addressed himself to me as a countryman, and he asked me to drink a glass of ale; he said, he knew the house, and I went in with him; and while I was in the house with him, he got acquainted with that unfortunate man at the bar; I was going to Charing-cross, to see a young woman that was going into the country.

What time of night was it? - It was half past ten at night; I do not know who the coachman was; I was quite a stranger in London; the prisoner got sociated with the coachman, while I was in the house; we staid half an hour, or a quarter of an hour in the house; I got into the coach; the blinds were up; and the prisoner got on the box with the coachman, and they drove out of town in a strange land; then this young man and the coachman came to the door, and bid me get out, for there were some ladies that wanted to go into the coach; I said I would not get out if the King was there; I said, I hoped they would take me a little nearer the place I was going to; this young man came to me, and said his name was
John Smith
, and I need not not be frightened, for he lived in the Strand; when they took me a little further, the coachman said, will you get out, if any body else comes in, you shall ride on the box; I got on, and they said it was not high my part of the town; but the coachman said they were going that way, and then they drove me out of town, another strange road; but I do not know the name of the road; I have been greatly censured in my character, and I have a right to stick up for my character as well as my property; my sister is tied up in service, or she would have appeared here; when I got out of the coach, I said I would enquire the way home; I had the bundle in my hand; the coachman said he would hold it, and he whipped it into the boot; and this young man set on the coach-box, and they went away with it; there was a black pursued the coach; I do not know him; I said, God bless you black, run after that coach, they have robbed me of my bundle.
What was in your bundle? - The things mentioned in the indictment.
Are you sure this is the man that was with the coachman? - I am sure of it.

Court. Did you tell the company that were in the coach, how they had used you? - They went on; the prisoner had told me his name was
John Smith
, and that he lived in Exeter-change, the second time they carried me in the coach to the other end of the town.
Mr. Garrow, Prisoner's Counsel. This strange road that you went to is Vauxhall-gardens, was not it? - No, your worship; the company were taken up on the road on some road.
After you had drank together, you and the coachman went into the coach out of town some where? - No.
Do you mean to swear that? - Yes, I rode all alone to Charing cross.
Was it at Charing-cross that the coachman got in? - No.
At what time did the coachman get into the coach, and shut up the blinds? - The blinds were shut up.
What time was it that the coachman got in? - It was the latter end of the night, which I suppose to be three o'clock.

You know you were together about seven hours? - More than ever I was out in my life; it was ten o'clock when I first set off, we were half an hour drinking a glass of ale; I lived at that time in Denmark-court, No. 14.
Now you live on Saffron-hill? - Yes.

How came you to take this coach at this time of night? - I was going to see a young woman named
Elizabeth Davis
, that was going out of town at three; but if I had been going on business of more consequence, that villain would have prevented me.
How many pints of ale did you drink together? - I drank a glass of ale, but if I had got quite drunk, it is no reason I should be robbed of my property.
By the time you parted in the morning, I believe you was pretty drunk? - I defy them to say so that I was drunk, or yet to say that they can disprove me, whether I am man or woman.
How many fares were taken up, and how often did you ride on the outside of the coach? - They took up two fares, and the prisoner was behind.

First you went out of town? - Yes, but they broke my command; I am not drunk now, I am rather confused at you; I wish to be as partial to the prisoner as any one, and to them all; I do not wish to be severe to any, and I pity the unfortunate, but I have been cruelly treated; I leave it to the Judge of the Court.
Where did you first find this man? - He was first taken by one Lucas; he was taken the Sunday after.

How often have you taken him up, and how often has he been discharged? - Once he was taken up by the constable before he was brought to justice; a second time he was taken up and brought before Mr. Justice Croft, then he was set at liberty; and after that he was taken up and discharged, at last he was committed.
Upon your oath did not you swear that this young man's brother was the person? - No.

Have you never had him in custody for this offence? - No, I never had him in custody; I gave him a challenge of it, and he went and charged the watch with me; I accused one brother in order to bring the other brother before me.
Did not you positively swear to that brother before the magistrate? - No; he was not carried before any Justice, I went at the hour they ordered me, and he never came.

Court. After you was used in this manner, who did you go to the next morning? - To the same place where I lived before, in Denmark Court, No. 14; I lodged with a woman that lives on the second floor; Mrs. Holmes keeps the whole; I was with her taking care of her child.
How came you by the bundle? - I had been out that evening a visiting in Mincing-lane, No. 25. I took the bundle out with me to work; the gown was half made and half unmade.

Who was that young woman you was going to see? -
Elizabeth Davis
her name was, she was going down to Shrewsbury.
Is the person here where you lodged? - No; she is a genteel person, and would be rather confused.

Who did you make your complaint to the next day? - To that person I lived with, and I asked her if there was not one
John Smith
lived in Exeter-change, and she told me no.
After this young man was discharged so often, who advised you to get him committed? - Justice Croft told me to go to Hicks's-hall on the morrow, and I should get an indictment.

I fancy the Justice told you he would not commit him, but you might go and indict him the next day? - He did not say whether he would commit him or not; I was wilfully robbed, and that is the man that did it.

Mr. Garrow. Did not the prisoner go with you and
Lucas
every where to endeavour to find the coachman? - He went to one master coachman.
During the whole time this young man was with you going about to find out the coachman, did you pretend he knew any thing about your bundle? - Yes, I told Lucas he had the bundle.
Court. Is Lucas here? - Yes.
Do you call him as a witness? - No.

EDWARD LUCAS
sworn.

I am a constable; I was applied to by this young woman about her bundle; I think it was some time in August, or the latter end of July; she came to me and told me she had been robbed; she then mentioned the prisoner, she said the prisoner could tell me all about it, one of the coachmen had cheated her of her bundle; I went down with her into the Strand, this young man was in the public house; she found him out; I understood she had been there before; she took me directly to him, when we came there I called him out, and asked him about the matter, and he said he was the person that was upon the coach-box; that the coachman and she were together in the coach, and he believed they had connections, or something of that fort, and he should be very glad to go with me any where to apprehend the coachman if I thought it was a robbery; he went with me to different parts of the town; we did not find the coachman; she then said, as you cannot find the coachman, I insist on your taking this man up; the man came several times to the office, she applied for a warrant, the magistrate refused it, it was Justices Clark and Walker; I do not believe the prisoner had ever been in custody above twice; there was a warrant granted once or twice, and the magistrates discharged him.

Do you know any thing of the brother of this young man being in custody? - Yes, one morning; as far as I can recollect, she stopped him somewhere in the street, the watch was charged to take him into custody; I believe he was in custody all night, and the next morning the young man was brought up, and she never appeared; he was discharged.
Have you ever enquired how this young woman gets her living? - Some say she's out of her mind; the magistrates thought so however.

JOHN BEAMISH
sworn.
I am another officer; I have heard the account of Lucas, it is true, I was present all the time.

JOHN STEWART
sworn.

I am brother to the prisoner; I was coming from Bagnigge Wells in the evening, and I went into a public house and called for a pint of beer; this woman was sitting in a box where there was a light, I went to sit in another box, says she to me give me that bundle; says I, what bundle? says she, the bundle you stole from me; says I, will you swear that? yes, says she; she said I was the person, and she said that she gave the gown to the coachman; the next morning I went to Justice Walker's, she never appeared at all; I was surprised when she spoke to me, I was a stranger to her; she was alone.
The prisoner called one witness to his character.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

866.
SALLY SEAL
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 14th day of October , one metal watch, value 20 s. one steel chain, value 6 d. a stone seal, value 2 d. a key, value 1 d. the property of
William Kennell
, privily from his person .

WILLIAM KENNELL
sworn.

I belong to the General post-office ; I was rather in liquor; I was going up Air-street, Piccadilly
, about eleven at night; and I went into a hotel in Air-street; I went into the first floor, and the prisoner was introduced into my company; she wanted me to stop all night with her; I told her I must go home; at last I told her, I would go home, and see whether our people were gone to bed, and I would come back; when I got two or three yards I missed my watch; I am almost sure I had it when I went in; I went back and asked her if she knew any thing of it; and she said, no; I took her to the watch-house.
Had you been with any other woman? - Not that I know of.
Had any familiarities passed between you and her? - Yes.

ROBERT WYNNE
sworn.

The prisoner was brought to me to the watch-house; I am keeper; she told me to go into the yard of the hotel, and look under the cistern, and I should find the watch covered over with some bricks; I went with the constable and found it there.
(The watch produced and deposed to.)
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

I was not willing to resign the watch till he had satisfied me for the time he had been with me; he used me in a very ungenteel manner, he left his watch on the sofa; I had been in company with him about three weeks before at a house in the Hay-market, and he behaved in the same unpolite manner; and it was merely out of resentment that I kept it.
What do you mean by unpolite behaviour, not giving you any thing? - Yes.
Court to Prosecutor. You meant to come back to her? - Yes.
Had you given h er any money? - No.
Do you happen to know or recollect that you laid your watch down? - I was in liquor, and did not know what I did, perhaps I might.
Had you any money in your pocket? - Yes.
Was your money all left? - Yes.
Prisoner. I have sent for my friends, but they are not come yet.
Prosecutor. To the best of my knowledge I never saw the young woman before in my life.
NOT GUILTY .

Court to Prosecutor. The best use you can make of the event of to-day, is to keep yourself sober, and you will keep yourself out of these sort of scrapes; you lose your property, injure your health, and ruin your character too.

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

867.
JAMES HOWSON
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 15th day of October , one silver watch, value 40 s. a chain, value 2 d. a seal, value 2 d. a key, value 1 d. the property of
Benjamin Coombes
.

BENJAMIN COOMBES
sworn.

I am a carpenter ; I lost my watch on Sunday was se'night, from one Buer's in Chandos-street
; the prisoner did take my watch; I went into Duke's-court in the morning and had a pint of purl, and from that time we went home to my lodgings, there he sent for a quartern of gin; I drank one glass and he another, and the landlord another; then he asked me to go to bowls, and I sit down on the bench, and laid my head down on the table.
You was in liquor I suppose? - No, he asked me what o'clock it was; I did not make him any answer; he took the watch out of my pocket, and went off with it, between eleven and twelve at noon.
How soon did he go off? - In about twenty minutes, or it might be less.

How came you to let him go off with your watch? - I thought he would give it me again; he lodged in Little Moore's-yard; the same place that I do; I went home the night I lost my watch, but he did not come that night; I found him at home, and in bed; I asked him for my watch he had taken out of my pocket; he said, he had no such thing; I asked him twice whether he would deliver up the watch he had taken from me; he said, he did not know any thing at all about it; I took him to the watch-house; I never got my watch again.
Do you say you was not in liquor? - No, I was very bad in my head.

MARY SILCOCK
sworn.

I have known the prisoner eight years since the Westminster association, he asked me a little trifle for rent; I went to him and asked him to settle it; he told me he would be with me on Saturday night or Sunday; on the Sunday evening he came between four and five; he was very much toxicated in liquor; says he, I cannot pay you, then says he, I am doing very well, I have got my watch out of pawn; and he had a silver watch in his hand; I knew him eight years ago to have a watch; he went away; I thought this was the prisoner's watch; I never knew the prisoner guilty of any improper action; he is a hard working industrious man.

Prisoner. I knew nothing at all about the matter till I was challenged about it on Monday night to my knowledge; I have not had a watch for some weeks; I have worked hard upon the spot seven or eight years; I never saw any watch; if I had been guilty of such a thing as this, many favourable opportunities would have happened; I had no watch to my knowledge.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

868.
GEORGE FLATHER
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Barnard Holbrook
, Esq . on the King's highway, on the 19th of September , and putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and feloniously taking from his person and against his will, one guinea, value 1 l. 1 s. and five shillings in monies numbered, his property .

BARNARD HOLBROOK
, Esq. sworn.

I live at the Grove-house, in the parish of Ealing; on the 19th of September last, I was robbed, about a quarter or half after seven in the evening; I was coming from London, between the Princess Amelia's at Gunnersbury-house
and Little Ealing
; a man passed my carriage and rode up to my servant, and ordered him to stop; mine is a post chariot and the box takes off; the servant was on the horse; he immediately stopped; at the same instant another man came up on the other side of the carriage, and one or both of them said, down with your glasses immediately; I put down my glass, and I believe my wife put down the glass on her side also; the man on my side asked me for my money; I immediately gave him all I had in my pocket, which was not less than five shillings, nor more than seven shillings; I took notice the man stroked it over his hand, says he, you have more; I told him, I had not, upon my honour; Sir, says he, you have a watch, give me your watch; I had dropped my watch down into the pocket of the carriage; I immediately jumped out of the carriage; almost under the horse's nose; the man backed his horse, and the other man called out from the other side of the carriage, Sir, get into your carriage immediately, or by God, I will blow your brains out, over and over, and over again; I cannot swear to the persons of either of the men, excepting that the voice of the man at the bar is exceedingly like one of the men; I sent my servant to Bow street the next morning to acquaint them of the robbery, and they sent for me about five or six days ago, about a month afterwards, and the prisoner was brought up.

Court. You went to the office in expectation of seeing some man there that had robbed you? - Yes, my servant said, he knew the man, and I went in expectation of seeing somebody that my servant should know.
When you went in were there many people in the room? - Not more than six or eight, I suppose.
Was the prisoner the first man that was fetched when you went in? - Yes, as soon as I came in, Mr. Bond sent for him immediately.

When the prisoner was fetched, was he shewn to you as a person that was under a suspicion of robbing you, or did you make any observation of him? - When the prisoner was brought, Mr. Bond asked me if I knew that man; I said, I did not, for I did not know the men that robbed me; and I immediately said, I am upon oath Mr. Bond, to speak the whole truth, the man's voice exceedingly corresponds with the voice of the man that ordered me to get into my carriage again.
Did you make any observations besides the voice? - Not the least; only the man that was on that side, was a very tall man.

How was it as to the light at that time? - It was not sufficiently light for me to distinguish exactly the colours; I could see white from black, but I suppose, I could not distinguish blue from black; all the recollection I have, I think the man on that side, when he turned round he appeared to have lightish clothes, but I cannot say with certainty; I took particular notice he was very tall; as to the faces of either of them I cannot tell; I do not think either of them were muffled; but I cannot be positive; nothing has been found; it was only money, and there was nothing singular about it; we drank tea in London, and left town about six, and we jugged on about five miles, or five miles and an half; we came from Moorfields in order to avoid the stones of the city; we went through Paddington.
Mr. Silvester, Prisoner's Counsel. If I understand you right, it was so dark that you could not distinguish colours? - Not sufficiently.
You made no observation at all on the person? - No, only that he was a very tall man.

THOMAS GUNNING
sworn.

I am a servant to Mr. Holbrook; my master was robbed of a Tuesday night about a month ago; about half after seven as nigh as I can guess; I was driving the chaise; he came up and said, stop, post-boy, stop, or I will blow your brains out.
Who came up? - A tall thin young fellow, in light coloured clothes, with a long face.
Should you know him again? - I believe I should.
Is the prisoner the person? - I believe that is the person.
Do you believe the prisoner to be the man? - I believe him to be the man; I am sure he is the man.
Why did not you say so at first? - I am sure he is the man.

Is it by looking at him that makes you sure? - I am sure he is the man; I took particular notice of him at the time of the robbery; the prisoner at the bar came up and said, stop post-boy, stop immediately, or I will blow your brains out; I stopped immediately; he was close to me; he came from behind; he was of the near side of me; he turned back and demanded the money; your money, says he; he did not demand my money; I am a servant; he demanded my master's money; he went on the near side of the carriage where my mistress was; the prisoner was not the person that went to my master.
Do you know whether your mistress gave him any money? - I cannot say; I heard none pass between them.

What passed after this? did he do any thing after this? - No, he swore at them that were in the carriage before the glasses were let down; he said, let the glasses down, or I will blow your brains out; my master got out of it, and said, if they were gentlemen, to behave as gentlemen, as they had got his money; he told him to get into the chariot again, or else he would blow his brains out.
Which of them said so? - I cannot say, they both said they would blow his brains out, if he did not get into the carriage.
Are you sure they both said so, or only one of them? - They both said so; I am sure of that.
Was the tall man on the side of the carriage with your master, or on the other side? - He was on my side.
Did they both speak together? - Very near together, but I cannot say which spoke first.
Did they both speak to you at the time you stopped? - Only one, that was him that was on my side, that was the prisoner.
Then at any one time, did you hear his voice alone? - I heard his voice then, that was the only time, the other was not speaking then.
When you went to the magistrates with your master, did you go in expectation of seeing the man that robbed your master? - When I first saw the prisoner, he was brought into the room.
Was you asked if that was the man? - Yes; I said, I believed he was the person by his voice, and by his complxeion.

Was there light enough to see his complexion at the time of the robbery? - Yes, he was close to me; he partly touched me; he had no disguise in the least; he rode up to me; I knew him by his voice, and by his long thin face, and his dress.
What had the man you saw in Bow-street the same dress on? - Yes.
What dress had he on? - A light coloured coat, a cocked up hat, and his hair tied behind; when I saw him at Bow-street, he appeared in the same way.
Had he a cocked up hat? - Yes.

Considering the situation in which he which he stands, his life depending on your evidence, can you safely swear, what you have sworn already, that you have no doubt but he is the man? - I have no doubt but he is the man.
You will swear that positively? - Yes.
Mr. Silvester. How long have you been coachman to my friend Mr. Holbrook? - About four months.
You knew the prisoner perfectly well before the robbery? - No, Sir.
What do you mean by complexion? - I know him in every respect.
But explain what you mean by complexion? - His complexion, and his height, and his thinness, and his dress, and his voice.
The man that robbed you, you never saw before; and you never saw him till a month afterwards? - It was very nigh a month.
You knew before you got there, that you was to see a man that was charged with robbing you master? - I did not mind any thing about that.
But you was told to drive your master to see the man that robbed him? - Yes.
And you had talked of this robbery to your companions, and says you, or says they, if we can convict him, there is forty pounds? - No, Sir.
You never heard of forty pounds? you will swear that upon your oath? - I have heard of it, but never heard any thing about my having the forty pounds; I heard there was forty pounds for somebody.
Court. When did you first hear that? - A long while ago.
Before you went to Bow-street? - Yes.
Did not you expect some share of it? - No, Sir.
Mr. Silvester. Who was to have the forty pounds? - I cannot say, I never inquired about it.
Do not you expect some of it? - No, nor desire any.

Who did you understand was to have the forty pounds, upon your oath? - I did not understand who in particular was to have the forty pounds one way or the other; I did not know the witnesses was to have any thing; I cannot say who was to have any of it; I never enquired about it; I never heard in discourse who was to have it.
How long have you lived near London? - Not a quarter of a year.
Upon your oath, have not your fellow servants told you, it would be a good thing to put a part of this money in your pocket? - No, Sir.
Did nobody say any thing about it at Bow-street? - Nobody said any thing about it at all.
You never heard you was to have a part of it? - No.
How came you to say it was light enough to distinguish? - It was light enough.
Is not your master a man of character? - Yes.
He says it was not light enough? - He could not see so well as me.
Your master was out of the chariot? - Yes.
And he says it was dark? - I could distinguish clear.
Now as to voice what was there particular in the man's voice? - Like the person's that is at the bar.
How is his voice different from mine? - He does not speak like you; he came up to me in a good humour.
How came you at first to say, I believe he is the man, two or three times, and then afterwards mend your evidence; was not you told to plump it now? - Yes, Sir.
Court. Did you understand the counsel just now? - No.
Do you know what is meant by plumping it? - No, Sir.
Did any body tell you to say any thing about it? - No, Sir, neither in Court, nor out of Court.
Have you ever had any conversation with any person desiring you to give any account of this business? - No.
Mr. Silvester. Could you swear to my voice to morrow, if you was to hear it? - I do not know.
You would forget it to-morrow, should you? - No, I do not think I should.
You would swear to my voice to-morrow? - Yes, if you spoke as you do now.

THOMAS CARPMEAL
sworn.
I am an officer of Bow-street; I received a private information against the prisoner, and I apprehended him on Thursday last; I know nothing of the robbery.
Had you any description of the man? - It was put in the book; I was not present.
The prisoner called two witnesses, who gave him a very good character.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

869.
THOMAS FOX
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 6th day of October , one gross of base metal coat buttons, value 3 s. one gross of breast buttons, value 18 d. the property of
Jacob Rellhoster
.
(The case opened by Mr. Silvester.)

JACOB RELLHOSTER
sworn.

I live No. 26, Vine-street, Piccadilly
; there was a fire there on the 2d of October; I lost twelve double gross of buttons out of my cutting-room, in the two garrets; I saw no more of them till the 6th of October at Messrs. Stiff and Wightman's; I do not know who took them; I saw a man go through the passage with my buttons, but I thought it was a friend of mine taking care of them, so I did not stop them.
Mr. Garrow, Prisoner's Counsel. In the confusion of this fire, you lost a great many things? - Yes.
Your friends got them out of the house as soon as they could? - Yes.
Had the box ever been opened after it came to your house from Birmingham? - No, Sir, I never opened it.
Then how is it possible you should know they were in the box? - I have since found a quantity of buttons, which answer the order I sent for to Birmingham.
Court. These are buttons, you had ordered from Birmingham? - Yes, they came in a box, which was nailed up as common boxes are.
Was it nailed down when it came to you? - Yes.
Had you sent the particular pattern? - Yes.
Did not the pattern come up with the box? - Yes.
Was the pattern in the box, or on the outside of the box? - Inside the box; but I did not see the pattern.
Had you any letter of advice? - No.
How long have you had them? - They came up in November twelve month.
Had you drawn the nails of that box? - No, I did not.
What buttons were they? - A plain yellow metal, perfectly plain, and white shanks to them.
Jury. Did you order your buttons all coat, or did you order them coat and breast? - Coat and breast.

FRANCIS UMPAGE
sworn.
I searched the prisoner's lodgings, and found the box broke all to pieces, and the lid off.
Have you all the pieces of the head? - No, there is one piece that I have not got; there wants a piece to complete the head of the box.
Is there any mark upon it? - Here is a mark No. 7.
What was in the box? - Only pieces of brown paper.
Prosecutor. I cannot swear to the box; I never observed, nor looked at it.
Umpage. There was no direction upon it.
- WIGHTMAN sworn.

I am in partnership with Mr. Stiff, in New-street, Covent-garden; on Monday, the 6th of October, between the hours of ten and twelve, the prosecutor came to our shop for some buttons; he came behind to my partner and me, as we were sitting at the desk, and told us, he understood a person was to come to sell some buttons; about one the same day, the prisoner came to my partner and me, as we were sitting at the desk, and produced two buttons, one of each, and mentioned that he had a quantity to dispose of; we asked him if he was the manufacturer of them; he said no, he had them of a taylor who lodged in his house, who was gone to Liverpool, and that it was all he had for fifteen pounds; we asked him what price he asked for them; he said, he could not think of taking less than four shillings and sixpence; he did not say, nor we did not mention, whether he meant the single gross, or the double gross, as we did not want an explanation, only to get possession of the buttons; we appointed him to come at three; about ten minutes before that, he brought the buttons tied up in two handkerchiefs; he put them on the counter in the front shop; I desired him to step into the back shop, which had not the command of the shop door, as I expected the prosecutor with his friends, to come at three; the prosecutor came in with two gentlemen belonging to the Sun-fire-office; and the foreman of the fire men, when he came in, he gave me a small slip of paper, upon which was wrote the number of the buttons, and the description of the buttons, and the quantity; the number that was affixed to them, if they were his buttons was ninety, upon which they just pulled open one corner of the handkerchief; I had not unpacked the buttons; I looked and saw it agreed with the paper, which the prosecutor had given me; and agreed with the numbers on the front of the buttons, upon which the prosecutor and the gentlemen from the office called the prisoner forwards, and untied the handkerchief; he was asked if they were his property; he said they were; one of the gentlemen belonging to the Sun-fire-office said, Sir, you must produce the person you had these buttons from, they were stolen, at which the prisoner seemed surprized; he was taken to Bow-street.
Court. What was the quantity of them? - Twelve double gross.
(Produced.)
Mr. Garrow. The manufacturers in Birmingham send up buttons which are numbered? - Yes.
So did the correspondent in London send down the number? - Certainly; if the manufacturer should send these buttons to a hundred different sorts of people, they would have been the same.
Have you any of them? - I do not keep any of the sort; I had them a very little time; it may be common with other button-makers.

THOMAS HALL
sworn.

I am shopman to Mr. Stiff and Wightman; on the 5th of October, between six and seven in the evening, the prisoner came to our house, and brought with him two patterns of buttons, the same as these that are produced, and desired to know whether these were buttons that we dealt in, and whether it would suit us to take a quantity of them, as he had twelve double gross of them, that he had taken for a debt of fifteen pounds; I told him if he would call on the morrow, my master would be in the way, but I could not give him an answer; the next morning the prosecutor came for other buttons, and asked if we kept such buttons, and described his loss and the quantity; he went to speak to my master.
Mr. Silvester to Prosecutor. Look at these buttons? - They are my property.
Mr. Garrow. Did you ever see them before you saw them at Wightman's? - No.
Who do you deal with at Birmingham? - I do not know him; a friend of mine wrote for the buttons.
Did not he write for that sort of button, that was numbered 92 on the card? - Yes.
If I wrote to him he would send them to me? - I do not know.
If any body had looked at this card for that button, would not they have found it 92? - Yes.
Now you have never seen these, how can you say they were your property? - He sent me white once.
How can you say he did not do so now? There is the proof of it.

Court. How came you by that paper that you delivered in to Mr. Wightman? - My friend who wrote for the buttons gave it me; his name is
John Young
; he is not here.

How came your friend to write it? - By my desire, because Mr. Wightman said, he wanted to ascertain the number and the quantity; and I went to my friend who wrote for the buttons, and he looked in the bill and there he found the number; I produced that number to Mr. Wightman, and the number and the quantity answered with these offered to sale at Mr. Wightman's; from all which, and the box being found in the prisoner's lodgings, I conclude they are my property.

Mr. Garrow to Umpage. Where did you find the box? - Down in the kitchen; when I went to his house, I asked him where the box was that held the buttons; he said it was in the kitchen, but desired me not to make a noise; it was publicly there.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I confess when they asked me if I manufactured them, I made an excuse, that I had them for a debt; the real fact is, that I found the buttons accidentally in the street.

MARY SMITH
sworn.

I am servant to Mr. Cooke, in Well's-street, Piccadilly; the prisoner lodged at Mr. Cooke's; I remember his bringing a box there; it was the box that was found by Umpage, on the 2d of this month; about seven in the evening, I heard a knock at the door.

Court. Was that the night of the fire? - I do not know; when I went up it was Mr. Fox, and he said, Molly, I have picked up a box, but what is in it, God knows; I asked him, where he found it; he said, in the street, on the pavement; he went up stairs; Mr. Fox said, take it in the kitchen, perhaps we may find an owner for it; the next day in the afternoon, Mr. Fox came down into the kitchen and looked at the box, and said, Molly, there is no direction on the outside, I wonder if there is any within; he opened the box, and there was no direction, only a parcel of buttons; he said, he did not think they were of much value; he would look in the paper to see if they were advertised; on the day that he went to sell them, he said, they were not advertised, and he might sell them as well as another.
Mr. Silvester. What is Mr. Cooke? - He keeps an academy.
How near is Well's-street where you live, to Vine-street where the fire was? - No great way.
You heard of the fire? - Yes.
This was the evening of the fire I understand? - I do not know.

About seven in the evening, whereabouts upon the pavement did he find it? - He did not tell me; he said, to the best of my knowledge in Vine-street; my master never comes into the kitchen; nobody goes into the kitchen but myself.
Did you look at the outside of this box to see if there was any direction? - Yes; there was no direction.
No mark upon it? - Not to the best of my remembrance; I saw none upon paper.
What became of the other part of the box? - I do not know; there was no direction on the box.

Mr. Garrow. You would have found no difficulty in burning it if you had been desired? did not you advise him to go to Vine-street where the poor people had been burnt out? - No, I had no business with it.
The prisoner called six witnesses who gave him an exceeding good character.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

870.
SUSANNAH REDMAN
was indicted for
feloniously stealing one quadrant, value 18 s. the property of
Hugh Edge Thomlinson
.
HUGHEDGE THOMLINSON sworn.

I received this as a security for a debt; I deal in coals ; I live in Great Peter-street, Westminster; I lost a quadrant; I took some goods in possession, as he desired me, and locked them up in a house, where I live now, in the Broad-way, Westminster, No. 4
; I had the lower part of the house for selling coals; this quadrant was in a room up two pair of stairs; the front room; and the prisoner lodged in the back room up two pair of stairs; it was in a bureau, which were part of the things I had in possession; as soon as I got the things in my possession, I put them in this room, and locked the door; I believe it was the beginning of last January; I did not miss it till some time in March last; I found where it was pawned, and whose name it was pawned in; by seeking for a ticket of Mr. Hill, I found out who pawned it; I knew it again; I saw it at the pawnbrokers; there was no particular mark about it; but I am acquainted a little with instruments; I am in the mercantile line.

Mr. Fielding, Prisoner's Counsel. You seem to be a very odd old gentleman; we have seen you in all the Courts I am sure: So a part of this house is where your coal-shed is, where you keep your few coals, and your sticks? - Yes, my few coals; I suppose Mr. Cassell might be indebted to me ten or twelve pounds; at the time he was in prison, I was such a blockhead as to let him have money.
How came this poor woman into your house? - By the instigation of Mr. Cassell.
Then upon that you received that woman into your house? - Yes.
Now you receive the things belonging to Cassell also? - Yes, but in the same room.
Did not you receive them things of Cassell for safe custody? - Of himself.
Was ever Cassell to have these things back again? - Whenever he paid me the money.
How many goods might you have received? - I did not take any inventory; I received them from different people.
Then you knew at the time you received these goods, that they belonged to the creditors? - I paid the money for them.

JOHN SYMONDS
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Hill; the quadrant was pawned by Garland, in his name for eight shillings; I gave a duplicate.

JOHN GARLAND
sworn.
I am a plaister's labourer; I pawned a quadrant, but I cannot swear to this being it.
Have you any doubt of its being it? - I made no remarks on it; I believe to the best of my knowledge it might be this.
Mr. Fielding. Did you ever see it out of the case? - Yes, when Mr. Hill took it into his hand; I cannot swear to it.

How came you by it? - The prisoner delivered it into my hands, in her own apartment, No. 4, in the Broad-way, Westminster, in the two pair of stairs backwards; she said it belonged to Mr. Cassell, and she said, she would be much obliged to me, if I would be so kind to go with it; I carried it to Mr. Hill, the same day she delivered it to me.

Mr. Fielding. Did not Cassell send you with it? - Mr. Cassell desired me, when he was in prison, to pledge something for him, and I carried this; I went by Cassell's orders and desire, and I got this and pledged it for him, and returned the money to Susanah Redman; she made no secret of it at all.
Court. How do you know this was done by Cassell's order? - Cassell gave me orders for going himself.
Did Cassell desire you to pawn the quadrant for him? - He desired me to pledge any thing I could, for he was distressed.
- CASSELL sworn.
I understand you had the misfortune to be in prison? - I had.

At the time you was in prison, did you give any orders about a quadrant that was in the hands of Mr. Thomlinson? - I gave him an order, whether it was a written order, I will not be clear; I sent him to the prisoner, and desired her to let him take my quadrant.
NOT GUILTY .
Court. This woman is very honourably acquitted.
Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

871.
JOHN MACMAHON
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 9th of September
, three penny-weights and six grains of gold turnings, value 12 s. the property of
Valentine Walker
.

And
PATRICK MACMAHON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, on the 11th of September
, knowing it to be stolen .
VALENTINE WALKER sworn.

I am a watch-case maker ; I live in St. John-street-road
, near the turnpike; I never missed any gold turnings, nor I cannot say that I have not; I know nothing but by their confession.

JOHN BECK HEATHER
sworn.

On Monday the 11th of September, the prisoner Patrick, who confessed he was the father to the little boy, brought this gold into my shop to sell it, between the hour of nine and ten; I asked the prisoner how he came by it, he told me, he gave four-penny-worth of oysters for it.
(Handed up to the Court and Jury.)

Court. Do you know this to be gold? - Yes; and afterwards he told me he had bought it of a watch-case maker that he knew; and I asked him where that man lived; and he said, Sir, I will tell you the truth; I gave eight penny-worth of oysters for it; I told him he must go down to the office in Bow-street, to give Sir Sampson
Wright
an account how he came by it; and I sent for a constable to take him before Sir Sampson; when he came there, he told Sir Sampson he gave eighteen penny-worth of oysters for them.
Court to Prosecutor. Can you swear this to be yours? - No, I cannot; a confession was taken in writing, signed by the boy, and I witnessed it; the boy was taken an hour or two afterwards.
Court. Was you present when the confession was taken in writing? - Yes.
It is a confession by the boy? - Yes.

Had you seen the boy before that confession was made? - I went with him from my house with the constable; he had lived in my house seven weeks an errand boy; he lived with me when he was taken up to the Magistrate.
Did he know for what purpose he was carried before the Magistrate? - Yes.
Did you tell him? - No; I went with the boy and the constable.
Had you any conversation with the boy before he went? - Not a word; in going the constable told him what he was taken up for.
Did the constable in your hearing tell him it would be better for him to confess? - No, Sir.

Did he tell him he would be prosecuted if he did not confess? - No, Sir, the boy began to make an excuse; telling me it was gold he found in the shop; I am sure I had not threatened him, or told him it would be better for him.
(The written confession produced.)
Heather. I saw him sign it.
Court to Walker. Was any threat or any offer made to the boy before the Magistrate? - No, Sir.
Was this a free voluntary confession? - Yes, we desired him to tell the truth, for he could make the case no worse; that was all that was said.
(The confession read.)

Middlesex. The confession of
John Macmahon
, charged with felony, the 11th of February, 1786, signed Sampson Wright.

"
John Macmahon
says, he
"has lived with Mr. Walker, watch-case
"maker, Islington-road, for about seven
"weeks last past as errand boy ; and that
"he has stolen gold turnings three several
"times, and he gave the other two to
"his father now present; that he told his
"father how he got them; that his father
"sold them, one for sixteen pence,
"and one for a shilling; that he left the
"last with his mother on the Saturday;
"his father not being at home; that he
"believes this to be the same as that about
"a month since, which he gave to his father,
"or his mother; but which he cannot
"particularly recollect."

PRISONER
JOHN MACMAHON
'S DEFENCE.
I know nothing about it; I never took it.
You now deny that confession you made before the Magistrate? - Yes.
How came you to make this confession if it is a false one? - I was advised so to do in the office.
Who advised you? - Several; I do not know who they were; they said, that was the only way to get clear; and if I did not say so, I should be transported.

PRISONER
PATRICK MACMAHON
'S DEFENCE.

I am a poor man, and have a large family; I was for many years in good circumstances; I deal in oysters; I met with a man in Piccadilly one night, he stopped me in the street; says he, how do you sell your oysters? I told him; says he, open a penny-worth; I opened him to eight penny-worth, or I believe more; I cannot recollect how many; and he gave me this gold for it; he said, he had no money; then I went to the shop, and had it tried, and they told me it was gold; I never saw the man before; I have eleven children, and never knew one of them to be guilty of stealing any thing; I am sixty years of age; my neighbours were all here to day but they are gone; please to ask Mr. Walker my character.
Court to Mr. Walker. What is the prisoner's character? - I never saw the prisoner before the gold was stopped.
The prisoner called two witnesses who gave him a good character.

BOTH
NOT GUILTY .

Court to Mr. Macmahon. You have been acquitted on this occasion for want of evidence to prove to whom this property belonged; and it would be highly improper for me now to say that you are guilty, but this I may say, I cannot conceive a more profligate and abandoned character, than a father that encourages his son in thieving; I hope this will be a warning to you; for if not, you will sometime or other be detected; and you may depend upon it that a man in such a situation will receive every punishment that the law can inflict upon him.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

872.
JOSEPH YORK
,
THOMAS AKIS
and
NATHANIEL ROBERTS
were indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 15th day of October , thirty-six pounds weight of black wool, value 20 s. twenty-eight pounds weight of black worsted, value 28 s. seventeen hundred and twenty-eight yards of black shoe binding, value 4 l. eight pieces of silk ferret, value 10 s. the property of
David Ferguson
.

ALL
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice HEATH.

873.
ANN WELCH
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 2d day of September last, two china cups, value 2 d. a china saucer, value 1 d. three steel buckles, value 6 d. two steel swivels, value 1 d. one cravat, value 1 d. two printed bound books, value 1 s. one ditto, value 1 s. one ditto, value 1 s. and one other ditto, value 2 d. the property of
John Fitzgerald
.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the London Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

874.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
was indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
James Dearing
, about the hour of ten in the night, on the 2d day of October last, and feloniously stealing therein, thirty yards of black mode, value 40 s. his property .

JAMES DEARING
sworn.

I live in Phoenix-street, Spital-fields
; I was not at home when my mode was lost; it was the 2d of October; it was cut out of my loom; there were about thirty yards; nobody was in the house, not a living person was left in the house barring the animals; not a christian person; I took the key and went to unlock the door, and found it would not open, though I was convinced I had unlocked it; I found it was bolted withinside, at bottom; I live at a house the corner of a court; there is a wall at the corner of my house; I jumped over the wall into my yard, and I found that my back window was open; it was a sash window that shoved back; there is a shutter, and there is a hole in it that gives light, and they had got a parcel of tubs to make a ladder to get to that hole, and had put their hands down that hole and lifted up the bar; and I found it in the yard; the tubs were right against the window; I ran to the drawers, they were fast; I opened the garret door, and halloo'd out I am robbed, and my neighbours ran in; when I found there were people below stairs that I knew perfectly well, I ran up stairs, there I found the shop door broke open; examining all the looms, I found the work out of one was cut off and carried away; I am positive the shutter was put up and the bar before I went out.

EDWARD MERRY
sworn.
I know that it was my work that I made.

JOHN ARMSTRONG
sworn.

I produce the silk; I received it from Mr.
Benjamin Abrahams
.

BENJAMIN ABRAHAMS
sworn.
I bought this silk of three men, on the 3d of October, between eleven and twelve in the morning, at my house in Petticoat-lane, No. 16.

What business do you follow? - A shoemaker; I keep a shoemaker's shop; the prisoner Johnson came to my house, the morning of the 3d of October, and asked me if I would buy any mode; I said, yes; and he called in another man; this other man said, this mode was in Frying-pan-alley; and the person he left it with lent him four shillings upon it; and he said, if I would send the four shillings by Mr. Johnson, I should have the buying of it; and says he, if you are doubtless of the money, I will remain with you, while Johnson fetches it; and he did remain with me; he went up stairs; Johnson went and fetched the mode, and brought another man with him; this other man had some mode in a handkerchief; and he went up and agreed for 30 s; and they sent for some liquor; and one of the men seemed to be in liquor; I asked them how they came by it; and they said, they had it from a friend that constantly came by; I asked them again, after sitting there some time, one of them starts up, and says, it has been cut out of a loom; that was one of the men that is not here; they went away; the next day Mr. Armstrong came to my house, and told me the Justice wanted me; I went there, and the Justice asked me, if I had bought any mode, to which I said, yes; and he told me it had been stolen; and he said, it should be sent for; this is the mode which I delivered up to Armstrong.
(The mode deposed to by Dearing and Merrick.)
I am thoroughly convinced this is the same piece of work; here is the fag end where it was cut off; which I have pr ocured, and here is the thread that runs through,
Merrick. It is my work.

FRANCES BURRELL
sworn.
I know nothing about it; I did make one after it was sold; I did not see any money paid for it; I live in Abraham's house up stairs; I believe the prisoner is one of the men that was in my room.
When did they come into your room? - I really cannot tell the day of the month, not yet the time; there were several men in my room.

What did they come for? - I do not know indeed; I was gone down stairs when they came in; I cannot be sure this was one; I have seen several very much like him since; I know nothing of Abraham's buying a piece of mode.
