Do you live with Abrahams? - No, I have a room up one pair of stairs; I was taken to the office.
Prosecutor. I was in the office when she was sent for by the Justice, and there she said, that the prisoner was one of the three men that came with the silk; she swore that upon oath.
Burrell. I did not see him; I was so frightened and flurried when they asked me if that was the man; I swore he was the man; if they had asked me ever so much I should have said the same.
Pray what way of life may you be in? - Why, I live along with a young man.
What young man? - Never a one here.
What is his name? - Why I do not rightly know his Christian name.

RICHARD ARMSTRONG
sworn.

I received information that three men were selling some mode; Mr. Dearing had given information that he had been robbed; I apprehended Johnson; and I apprehended Abrahams; he declared he had bought it; and he declared this woman knew the prisoner was one of the men; that is the reason why she came here.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

On Thursday about ten I met two men; one that was a weaver, that had lived in credit; they had two fish in their hands, going to have them dressed at the Duke's-head; I went with them; and we were having a pint of beer; and he says to me, we have a bit of mode; it is in pawn for four shillings; can you tell us where to sell it? says I, if it is our own property; and I went with them to Abrahams; says I to Abrahams, Sir, here are two young men who have a bit of mode to sell, if you chuse to buy it; and he said, if I can agree with them, I will; so one of the men said, it was pawned for four shillings, if you will give him that, I will send for it; he sent me down with the four shillings to give to the other young man, to get it out of pawn; they agreed for it; Abrahams paid him for it; and now says he, if you will go down we will have the fish dressed; you shall have two or three pots of beer; that is all I know or saw; the people that can prove it are not here; I did depend that I was not to be tried till next session, because they expected taking the other men between this and then.
Where do your friends live? - In Spital-fields.
Court to Prosecutor. Does any body know any thing of this man? - No.
To Armstrong. Do you know any thing of this man? - I never saw him any where but in very bad houses; I never knew a friend he had.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

875.
JOHN CLOUD
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 16th day of October last, thirty guineas, value 31 l. 10 s. and two half guineas, value 1 l. 1 s. the property of
James Kensington
, in the dwelling house of
William Cato
.
(The case opened by Mr. Silvester.)
(The witnesses examined apart, at the desire of Mr. Garrow.)
Mrs. KENSINGTON sworn.

I am wife of
James Kensington
, No. 16, Weymouth-street, Mary-le-bone
; I occupy the kitchen.

Whose is the house? - It is the house of
William Cato
; he lives in the two pair of stairs floor; the prisoner worked at Mrs. May's, turning a mangle ; he was very poor and low, and had been a great while, till since we have lost our money; I saw the money on the 11th of this month, early in the morning; I kept it in a little drawer, at the top of the chest of drawers locked; I wrapped it very curious in a pair of black gloves; the gloves were left open, and the money was gone; I did not miss it till the Monday following; when I missed it, I found something had been put between the drawers and the lock, and bad wrenched it down; I missed it going to pay our rent; he came down into the cellar the back way with a kettle, and came up again, and stood at the street door; the next day he never came to his work; on Friday he came to work, but was in liquor; on Saturday he was in a great hurry to fetch his things out of pawn; on Sunday evening I saw him so much in liquor, that he could not unlock his room door; which was a stone's throw from our house; he was a dressed like a gentleman; when I found the money was all gone, it struck into my head it must be Mr. Cloud, and so I thought by all these appearances; we held our tongues all that day; in the evening Mr. Connelley and him came in very much in liquor; and as they were going out, we asked him to come to work the next morning; he said he would; but he never came; we took him to the Magistrate's.

Was you present when he was brought? - Yes; he first said, that his cousin gave him the money; then he said, he worked for it; it appeared he had lain out in that week, in one way or the other, upwards of twenty pounds, with what he got out of pawn.

Mr. Garrow, Prisoner's Counsel. How long have you known him? - A great while; he has worked for me ever since the beginning of April; I have heard say his wife and him have lived very creditable; but very much reduced.

You have told us that this man had the things in pawn which he redeemed? - So he told us; I am sure I saw the money on Wednesday the 11th of October; I had put it into the top drawer or the bureau; it was my husband's money; he did not know there was so much as there was; he might know perhaps there was twenty pounds; for I have worked very hard these three years, because I have a small family; I did not tell him every thing; my husband never went to that drawer at all.
How much rent had you to pay? - Twenty-five shillings and nine-pence; and to our cow master about eight pounds; we had between nine and ten to pay.
How long ago was it that your husband borrowed five guineas towards paying his rent? - He never brought five guineas since I was married; I never said so to any body.
Do you know Mr. Earle, a shoemaker? - I do; my husband buys his shoes of him.
How lately had he occasion to buy shoes of him? - I do not know; about six weeks ago he had a pair, and paid him.

You do not know now that he applied to Mr. Earle on credit, and said, he was ceedingly distressed? - No, he did not, I am sure; I have been in the milk way about three years; my husband was a coachman; and when we came into business, I had seventeen guineas; we had saved almost fifteen pounds; my husband carries a pair of pails, and I carry two kettles, that carries a good deal of milk.
Have you lately sold any of your furniture or clothes or things? - No, nothing in the world.
Nor you have not said so to any body? - No, I have not.

JAMES KENSINGTON
sworn.

I am husband to the last witness; on the 16th of this month, my wife went to the drawer to pay the rent, and she told me the money was gone; first of all we called Mrs. May down, which was the woman this prisoner worked for; but at the same time I had no suspicion of him; I sent for Mrs. May and spoke to her about it; the next day I spoke to him; he admitted he had laid out in the course of a few days, not less than twenty pounds.

What account did he give of himself how he got that twenty pounds? - First, he said, he had it of his cousin; then he denied it, and said, it was money that he earned at three-halfpence an hour of Mrs. May; the prisoner was very mean and ragged, and was quite destitute.
Mr. Garrow. Was this money kept in a locked drawer? - Yes; I seldom went to it; I did not know the sum; I never applied to any body for five guineas; I never wanted it.

Have you never said that you have? - No, Sir; I know Mr. Earle; he is my shoemaker; I never applied to him for credit for any thing; I had no suspicion of the prisoner; I have known him since he came to work for Mrs. May; I knew him in the life time of his wife.
Court. This money was yours, you did not take it yourself? - No.
Nor you do not know how it went? - No, I do not.

ELIZABETH MAY
sworn.
I am a mangler, No. 16, Weymouth-street; I have known the prisoner six months, or rather better.

What situation was he in respect to circumstances, before the 12th of October? - His apparel was much as you see him now, but he had had a great deal of trouble with losses, and with the sickness of his wife; I paid him nine shillings and upwards a week, and sometimes four or five, or six, seven or eight, according to the hours he worked.
Mr. Garrow. His work was laborious? - Yes.

Of course you did not admit him to come in his best things? - No, I always advised him to come in his worst things; he used at other times to be decent as he is now; he had several things in pawn; I did not know him in his wife's time; the prisoner has worked for me ever since May; I am entrusted with much linen; I took him to be an honest man as could possibly be; and found him an industrious hard working fellow.

JOHN KELLY
sworn.
I am a broker in howshold furniture; on the 12th instant, I sold him a parcel of things, to the amount of nine pounds, thirteen shillings.
Mr. Garrow. When did he bargain with you for these things? - On the day he paid for them.

JAMES EVERETT
sworn.

I am a pawnbroker; the prisoner took things out of pawn of me on the 11th of October, to the amount of one pound, seven shillings and nine-pence; two waistcoats, one silver neck buckle, and twelve neck cloths.
Mr. Garrow. How long had they been in your shop? - Near a twelve-month.
I take it they were worth a great deal more than twenty-seven shillings? - No doubt of it.

DENNIS
M'DONALD sworn.

I searched this man's lodgings; there was a Bath stove, a chest of drawers, a bed and bolster and two pillows; he denied the box where his linen was; I was present when he was examined before the Magistrate, he said, he had earned the money at his work; he did not say what he laid out; I searched him, and found four-pence halfpenny in halfpence; here is a silver watch I found, and a silver knee buckle, and stock buckle.

MARGARET CONNELLY
sworn.
I have known the prisoner five years; I went to take some things out of pawn; I cannot recollect how many days it was before he was taken up.
What day was he taken up? - I cannot recollect indeed.
What day of the week was it? - I cannot recollect the day.
Was not you before the Magistrate? - - I cannot say; it was Tuesday or Wednesday.
How many days before that had you been with him to different pawnbrokers? - I only went to one that lives just by; I cannot recollect how long it was before we went to the Magistrates.
Cannot you tell the day you went with him? - Upon my oath I cannot recollect what day I went with him.
How many days was it before you went with him to the Justice? - I think it must be Tuesday or Wednesday.
You cannot recollect whether it was two or three days? - I cannot indeed.

What is your husband's name? -
Daniel Connelly
.

DANIEL CONNELLY
sworn.
I have known the prisoner these nine years; I was with him when he bought them things; I cannot tell the day of the month upon my word; he only came to me and asked me to take a walk with him.
How long was it before you went to the Justice's? - To the best of my knowledge it was six or seven days; I am not sure.

In that day where did you go? - I went to Mr. I forget his name, opposite the Middlesex hospital; he told me he was going to take a watch out of pawn, and some waistcoats; I went to no other pawnbrokers.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

I worked for Mrs. May seven months; and I laid the money by; she almost always gave me victuals then; and when I had done work for her I went on messages; I slept in a gentleman's house in Portman-square; that saved my money; that was something every week; I had a few things of my wife's that I sold; and I laid the money by, thinking to get me two or three things.

Court. Then how came you to lay it out all on a sudden; to lay it all out and get drunk, that does not agree well with the character of an industrious sober man? - I was afraid of losing the things; I never was down in Mrs. Kensington's kitchen in my life; if ever I was down, it was for a little milk for Mrs. May; I never saw a farthing of the money in my life.

Capt.
FRANCIS SEYMORE
sworn.

I am in the army, on half pay; I knew the prisoner for the space of three years; in two of which his wife, when living, washed for me at their own house, and he carried the linen backwards and forwards; I have known him down to this time, an uniform, good, sober, industrious, hard working man; I always took him to be honest; that has been universally his character.

DAVID WILSON
sworn.

I live in Chesterfield-street, Mary-le-bone; I have known him nine years to this time, a very good, honest, industrious, hard working man, that has been his character; I never heard a blotch in his character; he kept a mangle, and worked very hard to my knowledge late and early.

Mrs.
LEONORA HUDSON
sworn.

I live in Paddington-street, Mary-le-bone; I keep a house there; I am married; I have known him between seven and eight years; he has been employed by me the whole time his wife washed for my family, at her own habitation; he is remarkably sober, honest, and industrious, so much so, that whenever my mother had any business to execute, that she could not repose trust in a common porter, or even her own servants, she used to say, she would send for honest Cloud.

I believe that was his general name? - Yes; and if the clergyman of the parish had been in town, he would have appeared for him; when I heard he was taken up, I asked the prosecutrix how she came to have so much money by her; and she said, her husband had borrowed five guineas towards making up his rent; that was the way she accounted for having so much money.
Where was this conversation? - At the woman's where he mangled.
Was any body else present? - Captain Seymore.

Captain Seymore. I went with Mrs. Hudson, to enquire into the merits of the case; and that woman, I think I heard her say, she had thirty guineas in her possession; and I made reply to her, I rather think it is too large a sum for you to have together at one time, living in a cellar, in great poverty, as you appear to me; I do not recollect that she made any reply.
Do you recollect hearing any thing about borrowing five guineas? - No, not from her.
Mr. Silvester. Where is it your live, madam? - No. 9, Paddington-street.
Are you married or single? - My husband is gone to India.
How long have you been acquainted with Captain Seymore? - Fourteen years.

Then he and you being acquainted, went to this house? - Yes, Sir, we went first to the clergyman's; all the neighbourhood were interested for him; Mrs. May was present; and she recommended them as objects of charity to me, having lost their money; I never knew any thing of the people before; they seemed to be in a great state of poverty; four small children, in such indigence, as not to be able to realize thirty-one guineas; I did not go into their cellar; the children were all brought up to me to excite charity; the woman was very shabby, and very poor, and the children I did not look to see whether they were ragged.

What was it that impressed you with the idea of poverty? - Living in a milk cellar, and being brought to me with four small children; I told them, if the man was found guilty, they certainly would be paid by his being condemned; if he was not, his friends would make it up; the man's wife has been dead a year and a half; I have known him very near eight years; my mother died a year before Mrs. Cloud died, of the same complaint; he has mangled for me; this man, by his honest, good character, has recommended the woman to half the business she has; he brought the linen backwards and forwards to my house; and I took his recommendation of her as a washer-woman.

Mr. Garrow to Mrs. May. Has this man recommended you to any family? - Yes, to two or three; I mangled for Mrs. Hudson; he fetched and carried all my linen; I frequently gave him his victuals, and frequently asked him when he would not accept; he certainly appeared to be a saving, frugal fellow; I was present part of the time when Mrs. Hudson came; I cannot recollect about the five guineas; the prosecutrix had four children; I am very positive she had the money; she shewed it to me a month or two before.
Court. Do you know this Mrs. Hudson? - I never had the pleasure of seeing the lady above once or twice before.

Mrs. Kensington. Mrs. Hudson came into the shop, and a gentleman with her; I cried and said, it was a great loss; I said it was a great loss to us, as we had seven or eight guineas to pay to our cow-keeper; she said, it would be a great charity to make a collection for us.
The prisoner called two more witnesses who gave him a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

876.
CHARLES RILEY
,
THOMAS BUTLER
,
JOHN LACEY
, and
SAMUEL WILLIAMSON
were indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 22d day of October last, one wooden boat, called a wherry, value 39 s. the property of
George Crutchfield
.
(The witnesses examined apart.)

GEORGE CRUTCHFIELD
sworn.

I lost a wherry; I am a waterman ; on the 22d of October, in the morning, between twelve and one, from New-crane-stairs
, I missed her in the morning; we lose boats every night; I had lost my boat the night before, and found her on the lower side of Mr. Minitone's dock, that is below the bridge, close to the New-crane, not a hundred yards.

What do they cut them away for, a malicious kind of amusement or what? - They are cut away with intent to go a thieving and plundering on the river; my boat was locked on shore, to go away at high water; the headfast was cut, and she was taken away between twelve and one o'clock; I caught the four prisoners in her, on the 22d of September.

Where did you catch them? - Between New-crane, and King Edward's Tier; they were rowing; I suppose it was between three and four hundred yards; we had a boat on the lower side of the stairs, and a boat on the upper side of the stairs, with a proviso, that any body should come and take the boats away.

Did you see this boat taken away? - We saw them come rowing out from the stairs with her; we perceived them, and rowed along side of them, and asked them whose boat it was; and they immediately said it was their's; I looked at the boat, and knew it to be mine by my number; then we immediately took hold of their headfast, and towed them on shore, and sent for the watch, and they were taken into custody.
Do you know them? - I never saw them before.

Did they belong to any vessel that lay in any of the tiers that were round? - One of them told the Justice that he came to go into the Borough, that he lived there, and he said he came down to New-crane, to get over the water to see somebody at Deptford; they all pretended to be going over the water.
Were there any sculls in your boat when you left it? - No, I could see that they brought sculls with them, for they had a pair in the boat.

Jury. I believe it is a very common thing to take one another's boats; was there any mark or name on the sculls that you found on the boat, when you came up to it? - There were a pair of scu lls in her, but when we took hold of her, the sculls were thrown overboard, so that we could not see them.

WILLIAM NEGUS
sworn.
I am the watch; I took the prisoners in custody; about twelve, they passed by me with a pair of sculls; I do not know which man had the scull.

John Walter
,
William Eaglestone
,
John Legorn
, and
Peter Constable
deposed to the same effect, being with the prosecutor.
PRISONER RILEY'S DEFENCE.

I had been at work at the Hemp-wharf; at six I took my money, and went to see some ship-mates, and staid with them some considerable time; we went down the stairs, and called for a sculler several times; no boat could be found; this boat was laying on the stairs, that the scullers were laying at; going down, there were three men coming up the stairs, but whether they belonged to the boat I cannot say; I am satisfied that I am an honest man; I never was before any gentleman before.

THOMAS BUTLER
'S DEFENCE.

I belong to a ship in the river, the New Hope; she lay down at Deptford; I was taking leave of my friends late on Saturday night, my clothes and things were on board; I got in liquor; we called sculler ten minutes; this boat was loose, and we intended to make her fast over the water.
Were was that ship bound to? - To the South-seas; we all three belong to the same ship.
Did you tell the watchman when you was taken, that you belonged to that ship? - I did not.
Court to the watchman. Did you take these men into custody? - Yes, they gave no account of themselves, only they said, they cried scullers; I never heard any thing of it.
Did any of the watermen hear them cry scullers? - No, and we lay close too.

ALL FOUR
NOT GUILTY .

Court. I hope these men will be more cautious in their conduct: and as to the watermen, I desire they will not understand, that we do not mean to protect their property; if ever they catch people that mean to take away their boats, we shall punish them here; but if they catch people in this mischievous way, taking their boats to carry them over the water, let them take them before a Magistrate, and he will put them into a way to make them pay for it, and that will stop them effectually.

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

877.
BENJAMIN SMITH
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 21st day of October last, twenty-eight pounds weight of lead, value 8 s. belonging to her Royal Highness the
Princes
Amelia
, affixed to a certain building of her said Royal Highness, there situate .

BENJAMIN PINCE
sworn.

I am gardener to the Princess Amelia; the house from whence the lead was stolen, is in the pleasure grounds, in the parish of Ealing at Gunnersbury
; on Saturday morning, on the 21st of October, between eight and nine, as I was going round the pleasure ground, I missed the lead, and as I was going to Acton, in some fields, I saw some paint which had been laid on from time to time, and it had formed itself into a crust; I proceeded on, and continued to find some more of the matter; when I came to Acton, I still continued to pick up some more in the town; then I came to the place called the Steyne, there I continued to pick up some more of this matter; there are few mean habitations built for poor inhabitants; I still continued to pick up some more of this matter till I came opposite the dwelling of the prisoner; I went to the prisoner's house with two constables; they went in, and I went backwards into a little garden in which this house is situated; when I examined the garden round, under the vegetables, I saw some litter he had collected from a stable or hog stye; I turned it aside with my soon, and I saw that the mould under it had been very lately moved, which caused me to examine it further; and there I discovered the lead; I suspected it to be lodged there.
Was this garden belonging to the prisoner's house? - Yes.

What lead was that that you discovered there? - The lead that came from this temple; it was painted white; I applied it before several witnesses, and found it correspond with the building, and the dimensions; I left it in the care of an acting constable that served the warrant; it was rolled and beat up together; he confessed taking it.
Were there any promises made to him? - Not to exempt him from prosecution.
Did the prisoner say any thing to whom the house belonged? - No.

Was that confession taken before the Magistrate in writing? - I am not clear whether this last confession was taken down before the Magistrate or no; we could not promise him the favour of the Court; but we told him, we imagined it would be the only way to obtain favour; then he told us; and until we told him so, he never declared himself.
Court. I cannot hear any confession on those terms.

WILLIAM STOKES
sworn.
I am a bailiff to her Royal Highness; I was present; and saw the lead found; I saw it compared to the place from whence it was taken.
Did they correspond? - Yes; I do certainly belive it to be the same lead, it fitted exactly.
Do you know whose house this was? - Yes; Mr. Franklin's, that lives at Acton.

Who lives in the house? - This prisoner and his wife, and Mr. Jones, and
Fan Pearce
.
The lead appears to you to be newly out? - The constable had the care of this lead; I carried it to the temple, and then gave it to the constable.

WILLIAM GEE
sworn.

I am a fellmonger; on Saturday morning, about one, I was in the ground walking about; my grounds are very near the prisoner's house; I heard him knock at the door; my servant opened the door; and a light came; and I waved my hand to her to keep the light back; I heard two men talk; but I could not see them.
Did you know the voices of the men that talked? - I cannot swear to them.
Did you know the prisoner's voice? - I do not know that I did; I do not know how long he has lived there.
NICHOLAS BOND sworn.
I am a butcher at Acton; and a constable; on Saturday was a week, I apprehended the prisoner; I had the care of the lead; it was matched; it was never out of my possession.
Did you see it matched? - Yes, it corresponded; it appeared newly cut.
How far is the prisoner's house from the temple? - A mile, or farther.

FRANCES PEARCE
sworn.
Where do you live? - In the prisoner's house.

What are you come to say? - No farther, than the prisoner came between one and two last Saturday se'night, that was the day that the gentlemen came to the house about the lead; a man of the name of Baker was with the prisoner; they went round the house, to the back part of the house; I do not know what time the prisoner went out that evening; I only know what time he came home; after they came in they went to a little garden and staid an hour; and then Baker went away.
Prisoner. I never saw the woman that night.
Court. Did you see the prisoner that night? - I know he did not see me; I looked through a window; he was in liquor.
Court. Who lives in the house besides you and the prisoner? - Jones, and his wife, and a child.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

I was very much in liquor that night; I know nothing at all of taking the lead; this Baker was with me; and I believe he took it, for he went over into the garden; the women were all at home that night; and the lead was found in my garden.

STEPHEN STILLWELL
sworn.

I live with squire Holmes, at Little Ealing; I am his gardener; I never saw the prisoner till the 25th of this month; and I was at the public house at Acton, and Baker and the prisoner went home with me; it was near eleven when we set off; I got home about eleven or a little after; they staid about half an hour with me, and went out into the main road, that leads to Acton, a little before twelve; my house is about two miles from the prisoner's.

The Constable. My Lord, there were two or three came yesterday, to give the prisoner a character; as the trial did not come on, they went away; Mr. Preddy, his master, was one, with whom he worked a good while.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

878.
RICHARD ALLEN
was indicted for
burglariously and feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
John Marshall
, about the hour of seven in the night, on the 7th of October , and burglariously stealing therein, a silver watch, value 3 l. a silk ribbon, value 1 d. a stone seal, set in base metal, value 1 d. a key, value 1 d. his property .

JOHN MARSHALL
sworn.

I am a watch and clock maker ; I live at Wapping New-stairs
; I lost my watch on the 7th of October; it was hanging on a post at the window, on the inside of the shop, within the glass considerably.
What time of the day? - About seven in the evening.
Was the glass broke? - There was two panes broke at once, and another cracked.

Did you hear the crash of it? - Yes; we were at tea; I was much alarmed at the noise; I jumped up directly, and made to the door; and called the apprentice to mind the watches; before I got the door open, I missed one of the watches, and I immediately ran out and enquired of the neighbours which way the man had gone; I could hardly hear, the people called out so; at last I understood he had taken up the Orchard; it is a near turning; but little frequented of nights; I ran up there as hard as I could, and in the middle I met two women; I asked them if they met a man running that way; they said, he had just passed on; I still run on, and took hold of the prisoner by the collar; says I, it is you that broke my window and robbed my shop; says he, you are mistaken, it is not me; says I, it is; he said, he was going home, he lived at Hoxton; says he, I have some business in Rosemary-lane, and from thence to Hoxton; says I, come along with me, I will see whether you are the man or no; and I brought him round, and asked him where he had been, and he said, he had been to Deptford, and he walked there; I brought him into the shop; there was a crowd of people; says I, it is you, I am positive; have you got the watch about you? he said, no, it was not him; but he did not care, I might send him on board a man of war, he had no objections; so I sent for an officer; my apprentice had ran out after me, and missed me; I had the prisoner in the house; when he came home again, I opened the door to let him in; and my apprentice said, that is the man that broke the window and stole the watch; the man fell a crying; the officer came, and he was searched; we could not find the watch, or any thing, but a piece of a razor; we got a lanthorn to look for the watch, but could not find any such thing; I came back again, and said to the officer, what can we do about this affair, the apprence still persists in it; he was taken to the watch-house, and was locked up; and in about three or four minutes there came a girl of the town to him, and called him out, and said to him, Dick, have you got in the Watch-house! he said, yes; he told her to go go to the Blue Anchot, in the Back lane, and tell somebody to come to him; he asked her, if she had any money, he said, he was very dry; so we took in the woman and searched the outside of her clothes, and found nothing on her; as I was sitting at supper, my wife said, there was the watchman's rattle; says she, get up, it may be one of the thieves that stole your watch; it was a man was taken up for stealing some iron; I told the officer to be sure to search them before he put them in; he told me he had searched one and should search the other; and I said, I wish you would let me have my prisoner out again; I took the candle and looked all round the lock-up room, there I found this pistol laying under the prisoner, loaded, cocked, and primed; he told us that he had no money.
Did you ever find your watch? - No.

JOHN FORD
sworn.

I am apprentice to Mr. Marshall; I am sixteen; I was sitting in the shop, on a stool, with a cup of tea in my hand, and I saw a man looking at the shew glass two or three times, as if he wanted to buy, and the smash came in a minute; and I saw this man with his arm in, and snatch the watch, and he ran away immediately; when I came back, I found the man in my master's custody; and I knew him again directly; he was the same man.

Could you be sure that the man you saw in your master's custody was the same man that you saw at the shew glass? - Yes, Sir, indeed; I was about three feet from the window, but could see through the window clearly; there was a light about this far from the glass; he came and looked into the shop; it is a glass bow window, and this shew glass lays withinside the glazed window.
Then could you see enough to see through the glass to distinguish this man's person? - Yes.
Are you sure of that? - Yes, very sure.
Are there any lamps on the outside? - There is a lamp on the other side of the way.

THOMAS COLE
sworn.

I am an officer; Mr. Marshall sent for me to my own house, requesting me to come immediately, which I did, and went in, and had charge of the man given me; we went to searched for the watch in the Orchard, and we could find nothing of it.

Was there any other person in the lockup room, the time he was confined there? Not when I put him in, there were people taken for robbing a ship of some iron bars; I searched him, and found no pistol upon him; I searched him narrowly, without he concealed it in his stocking.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I know nothing of it.
The prisoner called four witnesses, who gave him a very good character.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

879.
JOHN SLIMMON
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
William Thompson
on the King's highway, on the 27th of October, 1785 , and putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and feloniously taking from his person and against his will, six pieces of silk for waistcoats, called gingham, value 3 l. 13 s. 6 d. his property .

WILLIAM THOMPSON
sworn.

I am one of the loyalists from America; I lost three pieces of silk for waistcoats; to the best of my memory it was a twelve-month ago; October, 1785; it was in Ratcliffe highway
.
Are they India? - They go for India; but I believe they are manufactured in Spital-fields.

At what time of day or night? - It was between ten and eleven; I was alone at that time; I was going down to where the ship lay; I was going to carry them on board the brig Henry, commanded by Captain Alton, going to Scotland; after I put my things on board, I went to one Mr.
John Swinney
's that keeps a public house, that keeps the King's-head, and I asked for a pint of beer; and there were some men selling these goods; I borrowed two guineas and a half; and the prisoner came in and asked me to buy some more; I said, no, I could not, I was going to a foreign country; I went out, and the prisoner followed me, and said, he would sell me some cheaper goods; I told him, no, I was going down to the vessel, and he followed me out, and he told me to stop; what do you want? says I; I want, says he, to sell you some goods, for I can sell some cheaper goods, for I want money; I went into another public house, and bought a guinea's worth for myself; I do not know the name of the man that keeps the house; but to the best of my opinion, he is a Dutchman; I went out to go the vessel, and he followed me, and advised me to lay by the goods; says I, no, I have bought them, and paid for them; says he, you are going down to Wapping, I will take care of them; with that he jerk'd them out of my bosom, and ran away; I fell down; I was affraid to cry out directly; then I heard the watchman coming; I thought perhaps he intended to take care of them; I could not find him while the vessel lay there, and I went on my passage; I had been twenty-two years in America; and I had some little dependance coming to me here from Government, when I came back again; I found out his lodgings when I came back again.
How soon did the ship sail after this? - In two or three days; I do not know she staid more; I cannot be sure which.
Did you lay any information before any Justice of the peace of this before you went? - No, Sir, because I could not find the man; I did not.
Were these sold you as smuggled goods? - I do not know whether they are or not; they were sold me as such.
Was this silk or gingham that you bought? - The chief was silk; I do not remember there was any cotton among it.
Is this prisoner a Custom-house-officer? - I never heard he was; I never saw him before that night; I did not know his name positively at that time, till the next morning; then I found out his name.
Mr. Garrow, Prisoner's Counsel. How far did he live from Mr. Swinney's? - I do not know.
Yes, you do? - It is in Fore-street; I am sure it is not half a mile.
Did you go to his lodgings? - Yes.
Before you went to Scotland? - No.
Why did not you do that? - Because I did not find it.
How long have you been come from Ireland? - That was the last place I came from; I have been home since the 14th or 15th of August.
Whereabouts did you take him up? - I did, a month ago; I cannot be positive.
Is it a week ago? - It is more than two weeks.
Is it three weeks? - I do not know; I could not find out his lodgings.

Where do you live? - Many people know I was a farmer in Georgia; I live sometimes at Saltpetre-bank; there are more Americans there besides me; I lodge up stairs at a public house, and two of us have a room to ourselves.
Did you go with the constable to this man's lodgings? - No, Sir, I did not; but I shewed him to the house.

Now, another thing, upon your oath, did not he let him go, and the prisoner came back to him the next morning? - I did not let him go; I do not know what the constable did; he told me that he took bail of him.
Upon your oath, do not you know that he let him go on his promise of coming back the next morning? - He told me he took bail of him.
Have you Mr. Swinney here? - No.
What might pass between you about it? - I asked him if he had ever found out where Mr. Slimmon lived; he said, he had not.
Were you and Callagan acquainted? - No, only I knew he was in the house the night I bought the things; he is a duffer; I was sober enough to remember every thing; I had drank some beer.
How much might you have drank? - That is out of the question.
No, it is not, it is in the question, it is the question? - I did not measure the mouthfulls I had taken.

How much money had you got from any body for this gingham that you said you had lost? - Three pounds ten shillings; that was after he was taken and committed to gaol, I got it, and was bound over to prosecute.
Who did you receive it from? - The tall man, that was his brother, and his wife; I was in distress for money; I was obliged to take some.
Do you mean to swear that you have any thing from Government? - It does not belong to this question.
Yes, it does? - Upon my oath, I had twenty shillings last year, and thirty shillings this year fro m Government.
Have you got any of those ginghams that you bought? - I sold what was remaining of what I had left in my chest; but all I had about me he took; I had bought more on another day.
And you took from this man three pounds ten shillings, what is become of that money? - I have laid it out; I never returned it back again.
Court. I hardly think it right, Gentlemen, after a man has taken the price of his goods, to believe a story that he has been robbed.
Jury. We are satisfied.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

880.
SARAH NEW
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Tapp
, on the King's highway, on the 17th of September last, and putting him in fear, and feloniously taking from his person, and against his will, one silk handkerchief, value 5 s. his property .

JOHN TAPP
sworn.

I am a seaman ; I have been at sea four years; I had been to Holborn-hill
, with a friend; I met a woman; she came running to me; it was Sunday, the 17th of September; she was in mourning, a good decent dressed woman; and she begged for God Almighty's sake, that I would take her clear of this woman; so I laid hold of the prisoner, and took her from the other woman; I bid her stand on one side, and she uttered some very bad oaths, and said she would strip her mast head for her; I bid her to stand back, and my friend, whose name is Cox, he walked on along with this woman; the woman went out of sight; when I let the woman go, I thought the other woman was then safe; she then followed me, and cut me with something on the face; she says, she declared she would lay me low, if I offered to touch her; she took the handkerchief off my neck; it was done with so much speed, and so much slight, that I did not feel it go; I used to wear it; I did not stop her; the other woman run into the road, and the prisoner run after her; the young man run after her, and came up with her; he took her in my sight; I ran after him directly as he run.
Had you light enough to distinguish her face, so as to know her? - Yes.
When she cut you, did she come before you? - No, behind me as I was walking along.
Did you turn about to look at her at that time? - I directly turned round.
Can you say of your own knowledge, that the prisoner is the woman that cut you in the face? - Yes.

Why how can you tell, she was behind you? - I know she was the woman that cut me; I saw the woman, but I did not see any thing in her hand; I am sure she was the woman that cut me; the young man run after her directly, and brought her back, and I searched her, and found the handkerchief down her bosom; I have two more handkerchiefs here, that came off the same piece; they were new; they were were the first time of putting on.
Prisoner. The gentlemen never mentioned any thing at the Justice's about being cut; what did I cut him with? - I cannot tell, but I mentioned it before Justice Walker.
When you took the prisoner, was she sober? - She did not appear to be drunk.
Prisoner. The young man gave me the handkerchief to go with him; I will be upon my solemn oath, that I never was out of Mr. Russell's company.
Did you take her up the court, and give her that handkerchief, and give her no money? - No, it is not true upon my soul.

SIMON STUART RUSSELL
sworn.

On the 17th of September, we were coming from the city, and in the narrow part of Holborn, we met the prisoner molesting another woman; she craved assistance of my cousin, and the company that was with him; the woman went with Mr. Cox part of the way home; she went out in the middle of the street to shun the woman; this woman followed her into the street; Mr. Cox laid hold of the woman, and rescued her from the prisoner; then my cousin laid hold of
Sarah New
, and kept her back from coming after the woman; she followed the prosecutor after, and struck him; I saw her, we looked back several times after the woman, and she came and struck the prosecutor in the face; I am very clear it is the same woman; she came behind him; I was walking by his side near the curbstone; I had like to have received part of the blow myself; we were going towards St. Giles's; she passed by my left side immediately, and she struck him; I saw her take his handkerchief off his neck; I could not see what she struck him with, because it was dark; it was about five yards before we came to the lamp; I pursued her, I never lost sight of her; there were no carriage
Had either you or your cousin picked up this woman? - No, and neither of us struck her.
(The prosecutor came to the Jury, who looked and could not see any scar.)

ROBERT MECHAM
sworn.
I am constable; I produce the handkerchief, which was give to me by the regulator of the watch.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

Coming up Holborn, there was a piece of work in the street; the prosecutor asked me what was the matter, and he drew me up a court, and he gave me this handkerchief, and I put it into my bosom; about two minutes after his cousin came, and knocked me down, and used me very ill, and said I had robbed his cousin.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

881.
JOHN WELCH
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Mary the wife
of
William Neale
, in the dwelling house of the said William, and putting her in fear, and feloniously taking from her person, and against her will, nine guineas and a half, value 9 l. 19 s. 6 d. the property of the said William .
(The case opened by Mr. Keys.)
(The witnesses examined separate.)

MARY NEALE
sworn.

I am wife of
William Neale
; I was robbed of nine guineas and a half; I do not know the month, or the day of the month; it was of a Monday, the prisoner came to me, and asked me for a lodging; he begged of me for God's sake to let him have a bed; I gave him some supper, and a pint of beer out of charity; I told him to go bed; he said, he would as leave lay on the chairs; there were more lodgers; I went to bed myself, and my child; he got up in the night time, and came to my bed-side, with a knife in his hand, and drew my petticoat from under my bed; I have but one room, which is a cellar, which communicates only with the street; there is a window over my bed; he told me if I made any noise or uproar, he would cut my throat with the knife; I had my young child in my arms, six months old; I was in dread to speak, and with the fright, I fell in a faint; he left my petticoat on the stairs; it lay under my head; and I saw him take it from under my head.

Do you mean by fainting, that you lost your senses? - Certainly, Sir, and my money too; he brought a knife in his hand to me, and told me, if I spoke a word, he would cut my throat; I fainted away when I saw him take the petticoat, and the knife in his hand; there was nine guineas and an half in gold; when I recovered, a woman was standing by me, and my petticoat on the stairs towards the street.
How many other men were in the cellar? - Indeed I cannot rightly tell, there was not many; there were not above five or six at the most.
How came the prisoner to know you had money in your petticoat? - He saw me sewing it in my petticoat on Saturday night; he lived with me two or three months; I never received my money.

When did you see the prisoner after? - I did not see him till he was at the watch-house; he left his shoes, stockings, waistcoat, handkerchief, and hat behind him; he went away only in his breeches, and an old check shirt.

CHARLES
M'CARTY sworn.
I went in search of the prisoner, at the desire of the prosecutor; I knew him before; I found him at a girl's room, in White-hart-yard, Saffron-hill, two days after; the money was gone.
What day of the week? - On Wednesday, at ten at night.

Did you find any men's clothes in that room? - Yes, some of the clothes he has on; there was a bed in the room; there was the appearance of his having been up the chimney; I first saw
Nancy Carty
; I never spoke to her before; I asked for the prisoner, on the outside of the door; there was a conversation through the door, on the one pair of stairs, with the man that kept the house and me, which might be heard in the one pair of stairs room.
What clothes did you find there? - A coat, waistcoat, and breeches, the coat he has on; I think it is a shag waistcoat, and corderoy breeches.

Did he ever acknowledge these things to be his, that you found in the room? - Yes, the constable knows that; I heard him acknowledge them; I found him in the one pair of stairs room under the bed; I found the things, some in the two pair of stairs, some outside of the door, and some on the one pair of stairs.

Did he appear to have been up the chimney? - Yes, he was in the shirt with a handkerchief round his head, and all over soot; I carried him to the watch-house; he said, he bought some of the clothes the same day, and some of them the day before; the next day he was taken before the Justice, and was committed; I saw the constable take a pair of silver knee-buckles out of his breeches, before he gave them to him; and the constable took a pair of silver buttons out of his shirt sleeves; they were the breeches he acknowledged to be his, and a pair of stockings.

DANIEL CLARY
sworn.

I was at the taking the prisoner,
John Welch
, along with M'Carty. (Deposed to the same effect.)

JAMES BESWICK
sworn.

I did not see the prisoner till he was brought to the watch-house, on the Wednesday evening, about a quarter after ten, I cannot recollect the day of the month, he had his clothes, all but his stockings; I rather think it was a brown coat, but it was a green shag waistcoat, corderoy breeches, no stockings, and a pair of new shoes.

Was it the coat he has on? - I do not think it was; I have a pair of new buckles that were given me by the houseman; he is not here; the prisoner said, they were his property; the prisoner asked me for them. (The knee-buckles produced, being silver.) Here are a pair of silver buttons, which I took out of the prisoner's shirt sleeves, the stockings are worsted; the prisoner owned the stockings; there was another pair besides these; he said they were his, and he bought them the day before; he gave four shillings for the two pair; they do not appear to have been worn.

EDWARD LUCAS
sworn.

I live in Little Russel-street Bloomsbury; I am constable; I suppose the boy calls upon me because I am in Court; this woman came to me, and said, she had been robbed of nine guineas and a half; it was in the beginning of September; I did not make any memorandum of it; she said, she had stopped a woman that lived there with her; I went and took the woman in custody in Buckerridge-street, and brought her up to Mr. Walker's office in Hyde-street; and there the woman charged her with taking this money; to the best of my knowledge, she said, that woman she supposed had taken her money, and knew that she sewed it in her petticoat; there was a little place in her petticoat that looked as if something had been put in it; I searched the woman, but she had no money at all about her; Mr. Walker discharged her; the prosecutrix then said, it must be a little boy they call Welch; she never mentioned a word about the knife, or about the boy coming about the bedside; but I believe our clerk took it down in writing, every thing she said.
I wish you to recollect this if you can, whether the prosecutrix did not tell you that this woman must be connected with Welch? - Yes, she did.
Did not she tell you that she and Welch had kept company together? - I did understand it, that this boy and this woman knew one another.
Did you understand it from the prosecutrix that they knew one another? - No, I did not.

When the prosecutrix made this charge, did you understand it to be a direct charge against the woman of taking the money from the petticoat? - I understood at the first giving the charge, that it was the woman.
You are sure nothing was said about the knife, or of the boy's coming to the bedside? - I am sure of that; after the Magistrate discharged this woman, she said it must be this boy, and not till then.
Jury. Did she mention any thing concerning the knife? - She never did upon my oath; and I was very much surprised when I heard the expression; that was my reason for coming forward.

ELIZABETH CUMMINGS
sworn.

I know nothing of the prisoner; but I was subpoened ever since last Wednesday, by one Carty; I have two houses facing this
Mary Murphy
or Neale, I do not know which they call her; all my lodgers were gone to work; about six I heard a great noise; it was on Tuesday morning; my husband's watch lay on the bed's head; I asked what was the matter; I asked whether it was a fire; they said,
Mary Murphy
was robbed; I went into the kitchen, and there I saw six people in bed; unhappy women and men; she told me, she was robbed of nine guineas and a half; I asked her who robbed her; she said, nobody robbed her, but her maid, nobody else knew where her money was, and it must be her; she said, she had her petticoat under her in bed; I asked her, where her maid was; she said, that she had been up stairs; and came down again before she would give her her petticoat which lay at the foot of the stairs; and that she was sure the maid had carried her money to one Fielding, who was taken up for the robbery that is now in Court; I came up stairs, and saw the watchman coming up Buckerridge street; he came to know when she was robbed; she never mentioned the knife to her throat, nor any menacing; and she said, it was cut out with a knife, and it appeared to be cut out with a little knife; Mr. Lucas came up the street, and was going to the cellar door, and Mr. Lucas took the woman into custody, a parcel of neighbours went down to Mr. Walker's, and Mr. Walker discharged Fielding the first day; I was there two days; I saw Fielding discharged; they sent the maid to the round house, to see if any thing could be collected from her; on the Wednesday the maid was discharged; one
Bill Neale
that lives with this woman came over to tell me as a secret, that she had taken up Welch for the robbery.
Jury. My Lord, we are satisfied.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

882.
THOMAS HANDY
and
JOHN JAMES
were indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 11th of October , two cotton shawls, value 11 s. the property of
William Hollis
.

WILLIAM HICKS
sworn.

The property was thrown into my garden; I do not know who threw it; I think it was the 17th of October; there were two shawls thrown over my garden wall; my house is about a hundred yards from the prosecutor's; I was going home about half past eight; I saw a man looking into a garden; I rather suspected him; I stood to take a view of him; I took him to be the patrol; I saw the prisoner Handy get out of my garden over the rails; I crossed over the road immediately and collared Handy; the patrol came up the same time and delivered him to him; the other was looking into the garden at the same time; I know nothing farther of him; after I had given charge of him, I went back in half an hour, I shewed the things to Mr. Hollis; the next morning, and he said, they were his, I am sure James was looking through the rails.

(
William Hollis
deposes to the things.)
Prisoners. We know nothing of it.
The prisoner James called four witnesses to his character.

BOTH
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

883.
ELIZABETH GEARISH
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 13th day of September , one linen handkerchief, value 6 d. one crown piece, and three shillings in monies numbered , the property of
Richard Whitehead
.

RICHARD WHITEHEAD
sworn.

I am a shoemaker ; I am a single man; the prisoner followed me in the street, at five in the morning, coming in the Strand; I was going to Bird-street, Oxford-street; I do not recollect the morning; it was about seven weeks ago; I was rather in liquor; she desired me to go with her; she told me if I would go with her, as she knew me, I should be safe, or otherwise I might be robbed; I went by her persuasion with her; she said, she had a good bed; I went with her, and laid down on her bed; I do not remember that I undressed myself quite, but I pulled some of my things off; before I got quite asleep, she attempted to get out of bed, and awakened me; I missed a crown piece, and some other silver; a soldier came to her assistance, and they both fell upon me, and the soldier ran away; I followed the woman into a gin-shop; there was a person drinking gin; his name was Taylor; but I cannot find him; the soldier came the second time and wanted to rescue her; but when he found he could not get her away, he ran away; she was examined in my presence; I found the handkerchief upon her; I had it ever since; I do not remember any thing else was taken; I do not know the house.

THOMAS DALTON
sworn.
I took the prisoner into custody; I found no money upon her; I searched her, and pulled out this handkerchief.
(Deposed to.)
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
The handkerchief was my own.
Prosecutor. I do not say the handkerchief was mine.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

884.
JOSEPH KAYE
was indicted for
falsely and feloniously forging, making and counterfeiting, and causing and procuring to be falsely made, forged, and counterfeited, on the 6th day of October, in the 24th year of his late Majesty's reign , a certain paper writing, purporting to be a codicil, and to be taken as the will of Sir
Robert Brown
, deceased, with intention to defraud Sir
James Brown
.
A second count, For uttering the same, knowing it to be forged, with the like intention:
A third and fourth counts, Charging him in the same manner as the first and second, only declaring it to be a will, instead of a codicil, with the like intention.

There was no-counsel on the part of the prosecution; Mr. Silvester and Mr. Garrow were of counsel for Mr. Kaye; but there being no evidence at all to affect him, the Judge directed the Jury to acquit him; and said it was a most shameful prosecution, and he had never heard any thing like it in his life; the Jury instantly found a verdict
NOT GUILTY .
The Court on application of Mr. Garrow ordered Mr. Kaye a copy of the indictment.

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

885.
WILLIAM FLINT
was indicted for
that he not having the fear of God before his eyes, but being moved and seduced by the instigation of the devil, on the 29th day of June last, in and upon
Mary Dixon
, spinster, violently and forcibly did make an assault, and her the said Mary, against her will, feloniously did ravish, and carnally know .

MARY DIXON
sworn.

I was put apprentice out of St. Martin's work-house, to a tambour worker; about a month or two ago I was sent to Tothill-fields Bridewell
for doing bad work , and tearing a hole in some muslin; I was in Bridewell a month on the apprentice's side; there was never another girl but me; I had a place by myself; and the door was locked at the first; I was locked in half the day, and the other half I was about the yard by myself; there was no other girl besides me; and the gate keeper left the gate open three days for that Captain that was in Bridewell to come to me; the gate keeper's name is Flint; I was standing in the cell, and this Captain, as they call him, came in and pushed me down, and put his hands before my mouth.
Court. That is not the present question.

Mr. Silvester. How soon after did you see Flint? - Flint served me with bread and water, and nobody else; and one day, when he brought it, he called me into the hemp-shop, where the bad people pick hemp; they had done work; it was their dinner time; I cannot tell the day; I believe it was the middle of the week; and he pushed me down between the bulks, and put his hand before my mouth because I should not halloo; and when he had done what he wanted, he threatened to flog me if I told the Governor or any body.

Court. But what did he do child? - He put his private parts into my body; I was afraid, and did not tell any body; I continued there a fortnight after; but he never let me out after, only to wash the cell; I saw nobody else; my master came about two days after; I told him, I was well, because I was afraid of being licked; Flint staid with him all the time; when I came out of Bridewell, my master put me to his journey woman, Mrs. Stunnell, in King-street, Golden-square; I did not tell her the first day, but she saw my shift, and took me to task.
Was there any thing particular on your shift? - Yes; I had clean linen only once while I was in Bridewell.

Had you any clean linen from the time that Flint used you so? - No, Sir; she took me to task about it, because I was restless, and I only told her of the Captain, because I was ashamed to tell of two men; but I told my mistress of Flint one day; I really think it was my mistress; it was a month after I came to Mrs. Stunnell, and I went home to my mistress's; I told her in about a fortnight after I went home; she asked me, whether any body had lain with me besides the Captain; then I told her about Flint.
Had nobody else lain with you? - No, Sir, indeed.
How near was this hemp room to the place where the people were? - It is a good way off; there was nobody else in the room but me and Flint.

Was there any body within hearing? - I do not know; Flint never staid with me at any other time; I saw the apprentice boys out; I never saw the Governor where I was; no woman came to me; the Matron never came to me but once, then she gave me a bit of bread and meat.

Did Flint take any pains to persuade you? - No, Sir, never a word; I struggled, but I could not have the power to move or draw my breath; he was down with me about five minutes; I told him of what the Captain had done to me; it was three days afterwards.
Mr. Garrow. Prisoner's Counsel. Was not you committed as a loose, idle, disorderly person? - I do not know I was more idle than the rest; I had ran away three times.
Where did you go on Whitsun Tuesday? - I went into the Park by myself; I walked about the streets all night without victuals or lodging; I have been twice in Bridewell for running away.

Did you tell this story to any body till you was again carried to the Justice? - I told it to my mistress a fortnight before; my master came to Bridewell to bring me clean linen; I changed it and carried out my soul shift to my mistress; she looked at it, and put it in a great tub of water; it was all stained.
Was it bloody? - I do not know whether it was blood; it was white stuff.
Was that the shift you had on when the Captain lay with you? - It was, and when Flint lay with me; I swear positively, that no man ever lay with me before the Captain.
Did not you change your things before you went to Stunnell? - No.
Have you any disorder on you? - I was not quite well; I always had such a pain.
Had you no complaint, no running of any sort? - Yes, Sir, I had indeed; I told Mrs. Stunnel that the Captain had lain with me.
Upon your oath, did you never lay with any body in the necessary in the Bridewell? - No.

Did you know an apprentice named
William Houghton
? - Yes, but upon my oath he never laid with me, nor never touched me.

Do you remember boys by the name of
Richard James
, or Hastings? - Yes, I remember Hastings; I had no talk with them, only they might say, how do you do Polly.
Did you never tell these boys that you would behave well for one day to get your clothes, and then you would go upon the town? - No.
Did you never tell Richards, that Houghton had laid with you? - No.
If you had called out and made a noise, might not the boys have heard you? - Yes, Sir, they might, but he put his hands before my mouth, that I could not call out.
When he had done what he pleased, what become of you? - He locked me up in my call; it was not my locking up time; I sometimes spoke to the boys through the grates.
Did you never see Mr. Fenwick, the governor, after that time? - I could almost swear it.
Did not you see him very often after? - No, Sir. I am sure I did not.
You told Mrs. Stunnel every thing you have told us about the Captain? - Yes.
Did you tell her you resisted? - Yes.
Did you work there? - Yes.
Did the Captain give you any thing? - No.
Have you never said he gave you a handkerchief and sixpence? - No.
No complaint was made to the Justice before you went home to your mistress? - No, I continued at home a month after I told her.
You was carried then to the Justice for doing some more bad work? - Yes.
Your master wanted to get rid of you? - Yes.
When the Captain came to you, could not the boys see him pass? - They might.

ELIZABETH STUNNELL
sworn.

This girl stept with me a month after she came out; and she told me the Captain had lain with her by force; she did not say what Captain; she was restless of nights, and could not sleep; and afterwards viewed herself much in the glass; I thought she had been with a man, she seemed rather bold; I then told her mistress; I did not examine her linen; she came to me with quite clean linen.
Court. Did that restlessness continue for any time? - No, only when she first came to me for the first three nights; she did not seem restless afterwards; she boarded with me.
Had she plenty of meat and drink? - Yes, they were very good to her.
Perhaps the sudden change of her diet might make her restless? - I did not think so, she used to clasp me in, her arms, and squeeze me very close a night.
Mr. Garrow. Did you take this to be restlessness proceeding from illness, or from lewdness? - I thought it proceeded from lewdness.
Is it true that you observed the first or second night any appearance on her linen? - I saw nothing, it was my mistress; she was a whole month with me, and never mentioned the name of Flint.
Mr. Silvester. Did she appear to be a loose vicious girl? - No otherwise than lazy and playing about, and gave her mind to low company.
Mrs. MATTHESIAS sworn.

I am the mistress of this girl; she was with me two years; her character has always been a loose, idle girl; I never saw any thing vicious in her; when she came home from Bridewell, I shifted her, and by her linen, I found she had had connections with a man; I did not tax her with it; I sent her to Mrs. Stunnell; she had been taken up four times; twice forgiven, and twice committed for running away.

Mr. Garrow. I am sorry to ask you the question, you must forgive me; you spoke of appearances upon her linen, were they such appearances as if it had been the first time, or such as would attend an ordinary connection? - There were no marks of that kind at all; it was marks of being concerned with a man.
Not at all as if it had been the first time? - Not at all.

I conclude from your opinion of this girl, that she is a very bad girl? - Sir, she is all that; she never opened her lips to me, or I should have seen into it; she run away again the last time, and we took her to Litchfield-street to get rid of her, and then she told this story; I never heard a word of it before.
Mr. Silvester. How came you not to tax her when you discovered it? - Because she was quite a bad girl, and I thought myself quite above her.

Do you a mean vicious one? - No, Sir, I cannot say she was vicious as to men, while she was in our house; but we have no men but what are honest; I thought, let other people find her out as I had done.
Court. Gentlemen, I believe your are satisfied.
Jury. Yes, my Lord.
NOT GUILTY .

886.
WILLIAM ROSS DARBY
was indicted for
committing the same offence , on the 2d of July last. There being no evidence, he was
ACQUITTED .

Both tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

887.
PETER DUNN
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 9th day of September last, a blanket, value 2 s. a sheet, value 12 d. a table-cloth, value 6 d. a waistcoat, value 9 d. a pair of breeches, value 6 d. the property of
Daniel Dean
.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

888.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 9th day of May , two house bolts, with brass and iron cranks, value 5 s. 6 d. and one brass mortised crank, value 1 s. the property of
Thomas Charles
.

The things were found at a stall in Moorfields, but not being indentified, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. ROSE.

889.
SARAR KENNY
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 9th of October , one half guinea, value 10 s. 6 d. six shillings and two sixpences , the property of
John Hunter
.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron EYRE
.

890.
FRANCIS MAKIN
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, seven shillings and sixpence , the property of
William Taplin
.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice HEATH.

891.
ELIZABETH BREEDON
was indicted for
wilful and corrupt perjury .
(The case opened by Mr. Silvester.)
BOOTH BRAITHWAITE sworn.
(Produces the Affidavit.)
I am signer of the bills of Middlesex.
Mr. Garrow, one of the Counsel for the Defendant. Do you know who swore it yourself? - A lady by the name of Breedon.
You do not know her positively at this distance of time? - I believe her to be the lady; I generally ask if that is their name and hand writing.
(The arrest admitted, and the hand writing, and that she sware to the affidavit.)
Read.

"That
John Cropper
stands
"justly and truly indebted to her in the
"sum of thirty pounds, for a carriage
"sold and delivered."

RICHARD COXHEAD
sworn.

I know Mrs. Breedon; I know
John Cropper
, the prosecutor; Mrs. Breedon lived by Bedford-square; she is a lady of fortune; to the best of my remembrance, about last September twelvemonth, on a Tuesday evening, a chariot was brought and left at Mr. Cropper's shop, and Mrs. Breedon said, she would call the next day, or the day after; I believe it was two days after, Mrs. Breedon was talking with Mr. Cropper, to know what he would give her for it, he said, he could not fix a price upon other people's goods; and she said, she was told seven years ago it was worth thirty pounds; Mr. Cropper told her, it was not worth one third of that, and Mrs. Breedon said, she should like to change it for a phaeton, and Mr. Cropper shewed her a phaeton, and they agreed for a phaeton, and to have the chariot in exchange.

Tell us particularly what the agreement was? - Mrs. Breedon was to give Mr. Cropper twelve guineas and her old chariot, and he was to have one guinea for painting her arms; it was a second hand phaeton, and was to be fitted up for Mrs. Breedon.

Did she see the phaeton at the time? - Yes, and the phaeton was fitted up according to Mrs. Breedon's agreement; she gave order for a fresh lining; and made in a thorough repair, fit for use; when the phaeton was ready, Mrs. Breedon sent about six weeks after, to the best of my remembrance, and said, she would not have the phaeton, and when Mr. Cropper read the note, he said, it was children's play, and he would not do any such thing, he would have his bargain, and he went on and had it done against the time; he sent to Mrs. Breedon; and she said, she would not have any thing to do with it at all; then there was a trial came on about it; Mrs. Breedon arrested Mr. Cropper for thirty pounds.

What did they together value it at? - Mr. Cropper said, it was not worth one third of thirty pounds; she was to give twelve guineas and the chariot for the phaeton, and one guinea down for putting in the arms.
Court. Which brought the action first, do you know? - I do not know.
Mr. Garrow. Did not Cropper arrest her for thirteen guineas? - I do not know.
What is this phaeton worth? - To the best of my judgement it is worth twenty or three or four and twenty pounds; that I take to be the value of it; I have not seen it since.
Have you a mind to buy a bargain this morning, I will sell you one cheap, will you give me three pounds for it? - I do not want to buy any such thing.
What is become of the chariot? - I do not know; I have not lived with Mr. Cropper for some time.
You was a witness upon the trial? - Yes.

You know that there was some one question that the Counsel did not ask you, that if they had asked you, it would have turned the verdict, and she would have the verdict instead of Mr. Cropper? - I do not know.

Upon your oath, have you never said, if the Counsel had asked you one question that he did not ask, Mrs. Breedon would have had a verdict instead of Mr. Cropper? - To the best of my knowledge, I never said so.
Upon your oath, after the trial, did not you say, that if Mrs. Breedon's Counsel had asked you one question, it would have turned the verdict? - I do not remember that ever I did.
Perhaps you remember what you write, better than what you say; did you ever write a letter to Mrs. Breedon after the trial? - Yes, Sir, I did.
Recollect what you did write, and I will refresh your memory presently? - I do not recollect.

Did not you write her thus, that if she would give you ten guineas, you would inform her how she might set aside all the proceedings against her, and put one hundred guineas in her pocket? - Yes, I believe I did.
Was you in Cropper's service then? - Yes, I believe I was.
What did you mean by that, how was you to put a hundred guineas into her pocket? - (No answer.)
Upon your oath, did not Cropper see that letter before it was sent? - No, Sir, I do not believe he did.
Will you venture to swear he did not? - Yes, Sir; he did not know of it.
Did not he desire you to write such a letter, upon your oath? - No.
How soon was this after Cropper came from the hulks? - I do not know.
What was you to do for her, suppose she had given you the ten guineas, what was you to have done. (No answer.)
Why it was to tell the whole truth, was not it? - Yes.
Mr. Silvester. Let us know what this whole truth and this half truth is? - I told every thing I was asked.
What did you mean to do or say for her? - That she always insisted that she never would have the phaeton; and it was six weeks after that she sent countermand
You did not swear that on the former trial? - I was not asked it.

Mr. Garrow. What conversation had you with Cropper, before the trial in the King's-bench? - No more than he told me to tell the truth; he never at no time, to the best of my knowledge, told me to conceal the truth.
Court. Were you sworn on the trial in the Court of King's-bench? - Yes.
What kind of oath did you take? - To speak the truth to what was asked me to the best of my knowledge.
Can you repeat the oath? - No, Sir.
Should you know it if repeated again? did you take oath,
"The evidence you
"shall give before the Court and Jury
"sworn, shall be the truth, the whole
"truth, and nothing but the truth, so help
"you God?" - Yes.
Then why did not you tell the whole truth without being asked? - I told all that I was asked.
But that was not the oath you took.
Mr. Garrow. Where do you live now? - In Charlton-street, Mary-le-bone; I lodge at Mr. Eaton's.

ELIZABETH HARRIS
sworn.
I was servant to Mrs. Breedon; I took a note to Cropper for her.

Court. Produce the note? - I was present in the drawing-room with Mrs. Breedon, when the tradesman and she were together; it was after I took the note, I brought the candlestick to take the impression of the arms; and it was a clear exchange; and the tradesman was to have twelve guineas, and a guinea to put in the arms; I heard the lady say, let her friends say what they would, the phaeton she would have; nobody was present but us three; I fetched a silver waiter out that had the arms on at the time; he was to go the Herald's-office, to see that the arms were right; I recollect nothing else; I fetched down the servant's livery, that the inside of the phaeton might match with the livery.
Mr. Silvester. When was this, my girl? - It was about a twelvemonth ago.
Was that before any action was brought? - It was.

Mr. Parke, another of the Defendant's Counsel. Will you tell my Lord and the Jury, where you got that pretty word, clear exchange? - I heard it a great many times more than once between the tradesman and the lady.
Did they use the word clear exchange? - Certainly they did.
What does it mean? - Why clear exchange is not goods sold and delivered.
I do not well understand what clear exchange is? - Why clear exchange is clear exchange.
Have you been in the service of an attorney? - No; she was to give twelve guineas more besides the chariot.
Did you hear that lady with whom you lived, say that it was a clear exchange? - Upon my oath I did, and I will swear it before a Bench of Justices.
Did you likewise hear her say, that a clear exchange was not goods sold and delived? - No, I did not; I heard her express that it would not be so much expence to have an exchange as to buy it.
You did not hear the lady say it was for goods sold and delivered? - Clear exchange is not goods sold and delivered.
How do you know that, who first gave you that information; you was not born with it? - My imagination tells me so.
Do you know a Mr. Brown? - Yes, I know him by going to the King's-bench with him upon the first trial.
Had you ever any conversation with Mr. Brown on this subject? - No more than if he asked me any questions, I answered him; I never saw him before I went to the Court of King's-bench.
Was not your name called by the cryer of the Court? - I was subpoened; Mr. Brown's clerk served me; I did not talk to him or his clerk; neither Mr. Brown nor his clerk knew what I could say.
Since the trial in the King's-bench, have you ever had any conversation with any person about this business? - I never repeated what I said there; I had nobody to speak to.

Where do you live now? - I live with one Mr. Elms, a stationer, near the Jew's-harp-tavern, Mary-bone; I never spoke to any person about this cause; I did not live with the lady; she was a lodger, and boarded with my mistress; I left the house where I lived, I was in view of a better place.
Have you never declared since the trial, that you was to do for the defendant at all events? - I never did.
Did you never say any thing at all about this trial? - I never heard any thing about it, till I was subpoened; it is a very disagreeable circumstance to me.

JOHN CROPPER
sworn.

Mr. Garrow. I think it my duty to take your Lordship's opinion on the question, whether he is competent or not; I have the record of his conviction for stealing a watch; his punishment was serving some time on the hulks; I suppose he served the time.
Cropper. I am a coach-maker .
Have you been a coach-maker for the last twenty years without interruption? - No, Sir, I have not.
There was a little interruption of your trade.
Mr. Silvester. I do not call him.
Mr. Garrow. He is sworn; he is the Court's witness now.
Mr. Silvester. Then I will go on with him.
Mr. Garrow. We have heard that it was a year's interruption to your trade? - A year! you make a mistake; it was only three months or thereabouts; I received the King's pardon.
Have you got it? - I have not got it, Mr. Garrow; I did not know it was necessary, Mr. Garrow.
Very well, Mr. Cropper.
(Mr. Garrow waved his objection to the competency of this witness.)

Mr. Silvester. Then Mr. Cropper give us the account of this transaction between Mrs. Breedon and you? - In September, 1785, the lady came to me, and asked me if I dealt in carriages; she said, she had a carriage in the country, and had no place to put it up in town; I told her if the lady chose to send for it from the country, she might put it in my place for a few weeks, till such time she had a coach-house, or some other place to put it in; a few days after the carriage came to my shop; I was not at home; word was left for me to wait upon the lady the next day at eleven o'clock; she was busy; she came in a coach to my shop; she asked me what I would give her for the carriage; I told her it was not the business of a tradesman to put a price on another person's property; the lady then said, that about seven years ago the chariot was worth about thirty pounds, as she was told by her coach-maker who made it; but twenty years before, it cost her sixty pounds; it was her wedding carriage; I told her that a carriage that was worth a hundred pounds seven years ago, would not be worth that now, as fashions alter; it was not worth one third of the money now; the lady observed she should like to make an exchange of her chariot for a phaeton, and asked me what she should give me with her chariot, for a phaeton and plated harness; I told her fifteen guineas; she told me, she thought it too much, she would give me twelve; I told her she should have it at twelve guineas and her chariot; she would have her arms; and I told her I would only charge her what the painter charged me, which was a guinea; she told me then, there was a matter she did not mention to me, which was, she could not pay me till Christmas; I told her that was not material, and she did not want it till that time; a few weeks after a gentleman came with her, of the name of Martin; the lady sent me a letter by
Elizabeth Harris
, who waited on her, that was about three weeks or a month after the agreement; I waited on the lady immediately.
