Have you got that letter? - No, I went to the lady, and she told me she was sorry to inform me that she could not have the phaeton, for she had information by her friends, that none but ladies of easy virtue rode in phaetons; I told the lady I had served a number of ladies of family and character with phaetons; the lady told me she would call, and bring a gentleman with her in the course of that day, or the next; I believe it was the same day she called with Mr. Martin; he asked me where the chariot was; I told him it was at the painter's; he asked me if he could see it; I told him yes; I went with him to the painter's to see it; Mrs. Breedon then said, I had made a great alteration in it, and asked me at the same time what would be the expences, if she was to take her chariot again, with the money I had laid out upon it; I told her, I thought it would be about twenty, or twenty-four pounds, the way I meant to finish it; she then said, she should have an objection to riding in the chariot, as it was her wedding chariot, and she should be affected with the thoughts of her husband; she asked if I could not get her another chariot; I told her at some expence I could, I knew a lady at Bath, that was going to throw up her carriage; but she came to town, and kept her carriage on; she said, in the course of time you may meet with one; I said I would endeavour to meet with one; I received another letter from her by this
Elizabeth Harris
, and I waited on the lady; and she said, I have considered of it, and let my friends say what they will, I insist on having the phaeton; this was about a fortnight after Mr. Martin had been with her to my house; then Mrs. Breedon ordered a servant to fetch a silver-waiter, for there was some difference she thought in her arms or crest, and a candlestick was brought to examine it; I told her I could not find out any, without I was to examine at the Herald's-office; she then desired a candle, and she would give me the impression of her arms and crest in wax, and the name of her husband she gave me in writing, to examine the family arms; and sent the servant to fetch the livery, to see if some lace she had seen in my shop was near the livery; she then told me to go on with it as I thought proper, till just before Christmas, which I did; and a few weeks before Christmas, I received of her a note to wait on her, and she told me, she had put by all thoughts of having a phaeton, and I must give her thirty pounds for her chariot; I told the lady I was not indebted to her thirty pounds, nor no such sum, but when the phaeton was finished and delivered, she was indebted to me fifteen guineas; she said, that if I did not pay her the thirty pounds, she should put it into the hands of her attorney; then I received a letter from one Mr. Allen, that if I did not pay her thirty pounds, I should he sued; I then went to Mrs. Breedon, I could not see her; I left my name; the servant came again at five o'clock; I went there, and I saw a gentleman, which was Mr. Allen, sitting by the fire, apparently asleep; the lady then asked me some questions about her carriage, and when I thought to pay her; I told her the agreement was an exchange, and I never thought of paying her any money; she said, she would sue me if I did not pay her; Mr. Allen at last starts up, pray Sir, says he, what have you done with the phaeton; says I, I have done nothing to it; then says he, oh, you have done nothing to it, that is what I want, now I will ruin you; I told Mrs. Breedon, I did not any way stand indebted to her in any money, neither should I pay her any money whatever; Mr. Allen said, he would ruin me, he would arrest me, and if there was a possibility of ruining me, he would; I then left the place, and went to my attorney Mr. Brown, of Rathbone-place, and told him my business; I arrested the lady for thirteen guineas; I went with the officer, and she kept me in the room till Mr. Allen was sent for, then I came away; I was arrested a few days afterwards for thirty pounds; and I was at Mr. Parsons the officer's, from between seven and eight in the morning till twelve.

Had you at any time agreed for the purchase of this chariot or not? - Never, I never thought of agreeing, as I always thought it to be an exchange; she told me, that seven years ago it was worth thirty pounds; she said it had been built twenty years.
Mr. Garrow. You have stated all that you know? - All that is material to my knowledge.

The last thing that you said was, that you never did agree to purchase the chariot, and that you never had such an idea in your life? - I will not say I never had such an idea, I thought of purchasing it when she first mentioned it, but afterwards, no otherwise than by exchange.

Why she said to you before
Elizabeth Harris
, it is an exchange; mind Mr. Cropper, we are not buying and selling? - No, I do not recollect these words mentioned as such.
Did not she say to you several times, it is a clear exchange? - No, she said, now I have changed with you, you will use me well; says she, mind I give you this money in exchange.
But at the time when the candle was brought, she said to you it is a clear exchange? - I do not recollect that passing at that time.
Did she say nothing about exchanging at that time? - I do not recollect.
Now master Cropper, I think you say you have not the King's pardon with you? - No, Mr. Garrow; did you ever read scripture, there is something there said,
"that there is more joy over one sinner,
"than over ninety-nine just persons."

Mr. Garrow. So there is joy in Heaven over one
John Cropper
that repents, more than over ninety and nine just persons that need no repentance; I have heard that nobody quotes scripture so well as the devil; he always does it to advantage; but he tried his hand once at it on the Mount, and was foiled you know; nobody quotes scripture so well as the devil, besides yourself; now, we did not get an answer to the question, we got a text instead of an answer: probably the place inspired you with some sentiments of piety? - I do not remember any thing being said about exchange when the candle was brought.
Do you think you should have remembered it if it had passed? - I cannot recollect every particular; when she came to my shop first, she said, now we have exchanged, you will use me well.

Elizabeth Harris
was present, she staid there the whole time I suppose? - No, she went to fetch the livery and the light.
You have told us all that passed when the lady came to your house with Mr. Martin? - Yes, I believe so.
They came to look at the chariot? - Yes, and they denied having the phaeton.

Do you remember saying this, upon her countermanding the phaeton, well, Madam, it makes no difference to me, whether you take it or not, for if you do not take it I shall get more by it in the spring? - Yes, I did say so; Mr. Martin was present; I had began to alter the chariot some time before.

And you told her if she chose to have that back again, she must pay you twenty or twenty-four pounds for the additions that were made; now, what is become of the chariot? - I sold it to a gentleman in Princes-street; I believe I sold it about two months before.
Did you sell it before you was arrested? - Yes, about a month before.
How much might this old wedding chariot fetch you? - I think thirty-six pounds or guineas.
Did you ever the phaeton? - I sent the phaeton home to the door; they could not take it in, they had no coach house.
When? - After the lady said, she would insist on my paying her; it was before I arrested her I sent the phaeton home.
Do you swear that positively? - I do.

By whom did you send it? - By
Richard Coxhead
, and Hoskins, and I went myself.
And that you are sure was before you was arrested? - Before she was arrested.
And before you made your affidavit to hold her to bail perhaps? - Yes, it was; because I was advised by my attorney not to appear against her till I sent the carriage and harness home.
It was not taken in you know, what did you do with it? - I took it back again.
How long did you keep it? - Not many days.
What became of it then? - The lady sent for it in a few days after she was arrested.

Upon your oath, did not it continue with you till after the trial of the civil action? - No, I do not think it; I am of opinion that she sent for it again in a few days after she was arrested, and then I believe it was not in my possession at the trial of the civil action, to the best of my knowledge.
Will you swear it was sent for before the action? - No, I will not.
How much is this phaeton worth? - About three or four and twenty pounds, harness and all.
Do you mean to swear that? - I gave fifteen pounds for the phaeton before ever I lined it or painted it, or any thing of the kind.
Was it worth fifteen guineas when you sent it home? - Yes, that I swear; and the harness was worth very near half the money.

You have told us that after the lady had countermanded this phaeton when she came herself with Mr. Martin, she sent for you again, and then she told you in spight of all her friends, she was determined to have it? - Yes.
You told us all that passed between you and the lady in the presence of Mr. Allen? - As near as I can recollect.
And you have told it truly? - To the best of my knowledge.
Do you mean to swear that he said that which you have stated him to have said, or any thing like it? - To the best of my knowledge.
I will repeat it. (Repeats it.) - It was that, or to that effect; that I am sure of.
Did you say, in the presence of Allen, that you did not care whether she took the phaeton or not, for you could get more money for it after Christmas? - Upon my oath I never did.
That you swear positive? - I do positively.
Nor any thing to that effect? - No, nor any thing to that effect.

Master Cropper, let us have one word more, now you scratch your ears it is symptomatic of the pillory, it locks like a presentiment; did you, or did you not say to Mrs. Breedon, that you could have more money in the spring for the phaeton? - At that time I did say I could have made more money of it in the spring of the year; says I, I could have sold it to a number of customers; that was in September.

You know at the time Mr. Martin came, you could not say that, because it was before you had lost any time; upon your oath, when Mr. Allen was present, did not you say it was immaterial to you whether she took it again or not, for that you could get more money for it after Christmas? - Never; that I do swear positively.
Did you never acknowledge in the presence of Allen that you was to pay or allow her thirty pounds for the chariot? - Never upon my oath.
Are you the prosecutor of this indictment? - Yes, I should imagine so; I understood myself that I prosecute Mrs. Breedon for perjury.

You pay the expences of the prosecution? - I have paid too much of it already; I did employ my attorney till I saw such villainous proceedings going on, I was obliged to put it into the hands of another; I pay the expences and nobody pays them else.

Court. Mind, and attend to my question, and be careful of the answer, what did you do with the chariot after Mrs. Breedon left it with you before you sold it? - I bordered, run braids round the roof and door; the perch was cracked, and the wheels entirely ran down; I took off the moulding round the roof, and down the hind pillar; I put plated bits and gores; and one hundred and forty, or one hundred and fifty foot of plated work round the chariot; I then put plated joints to it, which are about three guineas a pair; I put six head-plates, at twenty-four shillings a-piece, that amounts to the aditional sum that I sold it for afterwards more, than I valued it at, when I took it in exchange; I laid out upon it about three or four and twenty pounds, that I am sure I did not clear myself when I sold it, by allowing ten pounds for the carriage; I sold it for thity-six guineas or pounds.
Mr. Garrow. What time of the day was it when you saw Mr. Allen at Mrs. Breedon's, you said, between five and six? - It was in the afternoon.
Was not it between twelve and one? - I do not think it was; I think it was in the evening between five and six; I will not be too positive.
Court to Mr. Garrow. Have you any evidence to the value of the chariot? - No, I have not; it has been so altered.
Cropper. I would not give more than nine or ten pounds for it, if it was brought to my shop tomorrow; that is the extent of it.
Mr. Garrow. My Lord, I have many witnesses on the part of the lady, but I rest it here.
NOT GUILTY .
Court. This is as honourable an acquittal as can be.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

892.
EDWARD EVANS
was indicted for
unlawfully and unjustly receiving two pices of muslin , the property of Messrs
.
Acton
and
Eyre
.
GILLINGHAM EYRE sworn.

I live in Friday-street
; I am a linen-draper ; Rogers came to me as a porter on the 26th of November, 1755; I discharged him for being in liquor; on the Monday my partner looking over a parcel of long lawns, in my presence, we missed twenty-eight pieces of English lawns.
(Looks at his minutes.)

Mr. Morgan, Prisoner's Counsel. Did you make these minutes at the time? - Yes; there were twenty pieces of long lawns, twenty pieces of muslins, and nineteen of handkerchiefs, which we could not ascertain; the chief of the robbery was lawns and muslins, and some Irish, which people have been convicted of; the suspicion fell first on some carpenters; I sent after Rogers; some time after he came to my house; I then sent for a constable, and took him into custody; there were found upon Rogers, ninety guineas and a half and some silver; he was committed to Tothill-fields for a week; from thence he was brought before my Lord Mayor, he committed him a close prisoner; on Wednesday I went to Mr. Clarke, and told him the transaction, and he put me in a way; Mr. Clarke sent me to a Jew in Houndsditch; his name is Lee; I was sent to a man whose name is Farmer; who lives in Petticoat-lane; Farmer would not confess without he was excused; I attended the taking of the goods; the prisoner said, he had had the goods of Mrs. Haslam, who has been tried here, and Mrs. Haslam, in the presence of the prisoner, said, she did not know him.
What did the prisoner say? - God bless me, Mrs. Haslam, you do not know me! No, I never saw you in my life; that was the answer; he was then committed on that evidence.
Mr. Morgan. You mentioned that you advertised these things? - No, not the things, but I advertised the person, with a hundred pounds reward.

Mr. Garrow. This is the advertisement that brought us acquainted with your client, Mr. Morgan; you offered a hundred pounds reward? - Yes, on the apprehending and conviction of the man as described, and I conceived the description to answer to the prisoner at the bar.
How many times have you been in the prison to see Rogers? - A number of times.

MARY FREEMAN
sworn.

I live at the Bell in Friday-street; my husband keeps the house; I know the prisoner; I have seen him at our house in company with Rogers; it was the Monday morning after Rogers left his place; he came dressed in his best clothes; I says, what you have a holiday to day; the prisoner was present; Rogers said, he had a holiday, so he had got crumpets for breakfast; Mrs. Evans breakfasted there; Rogers said to me, it was very odd that he had met Evans that had been servant to his father; that was in Evans's presence; I never saw them together before; I saw him next day, or two or three days after.
Did you see them frequently afterwards together? - I cannot say how often; it might be half a dozen times; I believe they might spend a couple of evenings together.

SAMUEL HARPER
sworn.

I am one of the headboroughs of Shoreditch parish; I apprehended the prisoner; I had information on the 27th of February, about four in the afternoon I apprehended him; I stood at the end of Gravel-lane; I asked him what property that was under his arm; and he said, it was nothing to me; I took him to Mr. Wilmott's office; he made some resistance; he told me the property he had from Mrs. Haslam; these are things; then I took him and Mrs. Haslam to the compter; Mrs. Haslam denied knowing any thing of him.
Prosecutor. The marks are taken off these things, but we were robbed of muslins of the same quality; and I have every reason to believe this to be one of the pieces; we lost six.
Mr. Morgan. Then that you cannot swear to? - No.
Court. It is the very same sort of muslin you lost? - Yes.
Does there appear marks to be taken off? - It does; and ours were marked in the same place; a little of the ink came through.
Is not that the usual place for marking all muslins? - It is.
From the view of that muslin, in the state in which you now see it, can you form any belief that it is yours? - We had lost muslins of this quality, and I believe this to be ours.

From all the circumstances which you have heard when this muslin was found, I have not the least doubt but you believe it to be yours; but suppose you had found a piece of muslin in the state in which you have now seen this, in the shop of any reputable tradesman, should you have known it to be yours? - It is impossible; there is a hundred pieces in the bale; at the same time I have not the least doubt but it is mine; had it been found without circumstances of suspicion, I should not have thought of such a thing, and I could not have formed such an opinion.

Mr. Morgan. You have given a very fair answer to the last question, which does you honour, therefore it will save me a deal of trouble; I only ask, whether you have not, in the course of a short time last past, disposed of a great many pieces of muslin of the same sort? - Undoubtedly I have. (The muslin shewn to the Court.) This is the place where the mark usually is, and the ink being damp has made a little mark.
Court. Is it usual to take off the marks of the goods unless they are cut? - Not at all; I dare say there is not a piece of muslin out of that bale that has the mark off.

Mr. Morgan. But there is a possibility that the mark might be rubbed off by carriage? - I dare say it might be rubbed off; you see it has been rubbed off; it is gummed paper; it is not easy to rub off; there is something at the corner which appears to be India characters.

TIMOTHY HEALD
sworn.
I have been conversant with this business and this shop nearly three years.
Look at that property, and see does it answer your master's? - It is the same kind.
Court. Is that the same kind of muslin that Mr. Eyre lost? - It is.
Can you judge from the appearance of that piece whether any mark has been taken off? - There certainly has.
If that mark had been on, would it have led you to identify the piece? - It would have told directly.

RICHARD ROGERS
sworn.
I lived with the prosecutor nine weeks; I knew the defendant many years ago.
Mr. Garrow. While you lived with Messrs. Acton and Eyre, did you take any muslin from them? - Yes, I did.

What did you do with it? - Haslam had a good deal of it, and different people; on the Monday morning after I came from my master's, I went to Haslam's, and after I had been there a few minutes Evans came up stairs; I asked him if he was not the person who had lived with my father; and he said, he was; I told him to go to the Bell in Noble-street; I would come to him; the Bell was then kept by Mr. Freeman.

What passed between you? - Talking of one thing or another; he said, he had some goods of Mrs. Haslam, and she had told him they were one Rogers's goods, but that he did not think it was me; he said, he had bought a good many things of her; and most of the things Mrs. Haslam had of me; and he asked me if I had any thing, and he would give me ready money for it; I said, there were some at Mrs. Haslam's, and I would fetch them over directly; I went over and fetched one whole piece of lawn, and another of which about two yards had been cut off.

Was that part of Mr. Eyre's muslin? - It was; when I brought them to the Bell, Evans and me went into the parlour to look at them; and agreed for them; I think he was to give me two guineas and a half for each of them; I received from him I think, four pounds fifteen shillings in the whole; we stopped there, and a man came in and went out with him; the next day I saw him again at the Bell, and there was a whole piece of plain muslin, and half a piece of striped; he gave me four guineas and a half for the whole piece; but I cannot say what the other was.

How came you to meet him again that day? - He promised to come that day to have some more; he said, he would come if I had any thing else, and he would give me ready money for them if it was ever so much.

How often did you meet him afterwards? - I do not know whether it was the next day, or the Thursday, at the Cooper's Arms; we were first at the Bell by appointment, and then we went down to the Cooper's Arms; he had a patch or two of callico then to make a gown.
These things that you sold to him were all the property of Messrs. Eyre and Acton? - They were.
Do you know the real value of them, did you sell them at the highest possible price? - I do not know what they were worth.
Were the marks on when you delivered them? - I am not sure of that; I never took the marks off.
Mr. Morgan. Did you tell him how you came by the goods? - I told him I left my place, and I thought they knew nothing about them.
What did you tell him? - He mentioned different porters; and said, he had some of them; he said, he could not deal with Kent, he was too dear.
Mr. Garrow. Repeat what you said just now? - I said I left my place, and I thought there was no suspicion of me; then he asked me where I lived; and I told him I had left my place.
Did he ask you where you got these goods you were selling to him? - I cannot say whether he asked me or not, but he asked whether the marks were in.
What answer did you make him? - I told him I did know, I thought Mrs. Haslam took them out generally.
Did he look to see whether the marks were in? - Yes, he did look when he was opening them.
Mr. Morgan. Did not you tell him they were smuggled goods? - No, Sir, I did not.
You say that upon your oath, nor even hint it to him? - No, I did not; he knew very well where they came from; I never told the prisoner that Mr. Eyre did deal in smuggled goods.
Did not you tell him that you had lived at a tavern? - I did.
Did you tell him that you lived at a tavern at that time? - I cannot remember that he asked me any thing about it; I told him what place I lived at in town.
You have been both in custody togegether? - He was in custody when I was.
Was not you in the same prison? - Yes.

Did not you sleep together some nights? - We did one or two nights; I told him nothing any farther, than that I should speak the truth, and that I must speak the truth I never told him that; Mr. Eyre had been several times.

Did not you tell the prisoner, during the time you slept with him, that Mr. Eyre threatened you, if you did not convict him, he would lock you up? do you remember any particular conversation that you had with Hyam Moses? - I do not know Hyam Moses as I know of.
Do you remember having any conversation with any one of the prisoners, or any one in the prison respecting this prosecution? - No, Sir.
Did not you say that another witness was wanting to make your evidence be confirmed? - I never heard any thing at all about it.
Did you ever tell Moses, or any body so? - No, Sir, nor never heard any thing of it till now.
When were the last goods you sold this man? - It was on a Thursday, I do not know the day of the month, it was the same week.
The Remainder of this Trial in the next Part which will be published in a few Days.

Being the EIGHTH SESSION in the Mayoralty of The Right Hon.
THOMAS WRIGHT
,
LORD MAYOR
OF THE CITY OF LONDON.
TAKEN IN SHORT-HAND BY E. HODGSON, PROFESSOR OF SHORT-HAND; And Published by Authority.
NUMBER VIII. PART XIII.
LONDON:
Printed for E. HODGSON (the Proprietor) And Sold by J. WALMSLAY, No. 35, Chancery Lane, and S. BLADON, No. 13, Pater-noster Row.
MDCCLXXXVI.
THE WHOLE PROCEEDINGS UPON THE
KING's Commission of the Peace, Oyer and Terminer, and Gaol Delivery for the CITY of LONDON, &c.

Continuation of the Trial of
Edward Evans
.

Court. I think you said that before that Monday when you met him at Haslam's, you had not seen him for a dozen years? - I never saw him while I lived with my master, nor at the meeting with the taylor. (The piece shewn to Rogers.) It was one just like that, a heavy piece, I cannot be sure; it was a whole piece.
Prosecutor. They all run the same length; this piece is worth three pounds ten shillings, or four pounds.
Court. Then this man made a very hard bargain if it was worth then four pounds.
Court to Rogers. What did he give you for the piece of plain muslin? - To the best of my knowledge, four guineas and a half.
The prisoner called two witnesses to his character.
GUILTY .
Court. Let this prisoner receive sentence with the others concerned in the same transaction.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

wilful and corrupt perjury , on the trial of
William Watts
at the Old Bailey.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

894.

was indicted for the
same offence .
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

895.

wilful and corrupt perjury in the Court of King's-bench , in Easter term, in the 23d year of his Majesty's reign , upon an affidavit, in a cause in which he was plaintiff, Ormand
and Butler
were defendants.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

896.
PAUL STOKER
was indicted for
wilful and corrupt perjury , in his answer to a bill in the Court of Exchequer.
NOT GUILTY .

897,

was
indicted for the same offence .

Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

William Brown
, whose sentence was respited last session, was set to the bar, and ordered to be
privately whipped and discharged .

and

James Rudd
and

.

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

, alias Terry,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

, Hardwick Richardson,

,
William Bass
, Tamasin Allen, alias Boddington,
Michael Quin
,

, whose sentence was respited last session, was set to the bar, and ordered to be

Mr. HODGSON

RESPECTFULLY returns his most grateful Thanks to his Employers and Pupils, for the Preference they have thought proper to give to his Mode of teaching and writing SHORT-HAND, which he flatters himself is at once as concise and correct as any other System; he continues teaching in four Hours, by four Lessons, the whole necessary Instructions in this much approved Art. He also takes Trials and Arguments with the utmost Care, which are copied so expeditiously as to be sent home the same Evening, if required.

Mr. HODGSON (without the smallest Imputation on the Systems of his Cotemporaries, whose Merits he chearfully acknowledges) pledges himself to take nothing for his Transcripts, if any Gentleman who solicits a Cause, or the Counsel whose Arguments he professes to take, are not compleatly satisfied with his Performances.
No. 35, Chancery-lane.

A new Edition (being the third) of HODGSON'S TREATISE ON SHORT-HAND, being a sufficient Instructor of itself, is just reprinted, and Mr. Hodgson in order to accommodate all sorts of Purchasers, has reduced the Price to Eighteen pence only; also his new Publication, entitled,
"SHORT-HAND CONTRACTIONS, adapted to every System of
"Short-Hand; to which are added, a Comparative Table of Short-Hand Alphabets,

"and two Extracts by way of Specimen; with two Copper-plates annexed," Price only 2 s. 6 d. are sold by J. Walmsley, Chancery-lane, and also by Bladon, Matthews, Egerton, Fourdrinier, and all the Booksellers.
Letters (post paid) from Purchasers of either of his Books, directed to Mr. Hodgson, No. 35, Chancery-Lane, will receive immediate Answers.

N. B. The trials which have been much enquired after, Mr. Hodgson has reprinted for the accommodation of his customers, and are as follow: - The remarkable trial of
John Graham
and his Wife for forgery. -
Charlotte Goodall
and
John Edmonds
for robbing Mrs. Fortescue at Tottenham. -
Francis Gray
for the murder of Mr. Hurd. Dr.
Daniel
M'Ginnis for the murder of Mr. Hardy. -
William Wynne Ryland
for forgery. - Nicholson, Ward, Shaw, Murray, O'Brien, and others, for the murder of
Nicholas Casson
, at the Hustings at Covent-Garden. -
Richard Corbett
, (a youth) for setting fire to his master's house. - Colonel
Cosmo Gordon
for the murder of
Frederick Thomas
, Esq; in a duel. -
Henry Morgan
for the murder of Mr. Linton. - Porter
Rideout
, for the murder of
Moses Lazarus
, Duke's Place. - Captain
Kenith Mackenzie
, for the murder of Kenith
Murray Mackenzie
, at Fort Morea, in Africa. -
Thomas Wood
and
George Brown
for robbing Sir
Thomas Davenport
. -
George Ollive
, (a youth) for setting fire to the house of his master Mr. Parsloe, in St. James's-street. -
Martin Taylor
and
Elizabeth Taylor
, (brother and sister) both executed for burglary - Also the remarkable trials of Messrs. Goodridge's and Evans, for forgery. - and of
John Hogan
, (the black), for the murder of
Ann Hunt
; with many others too tedious to enumerate.

Mr. Hodgson has just bound up a compleat Set of Sessions Papers, for the last sixteen Years, which he will dispose of; or any person wishing to see any particular Trial, may have an Inspection of the same, or take a Copy of it, at the usual Prices.
